39246650.review:
A.A.C. is a colorful twin-stick shooter featuring silky-smooth gameplay and a variety of characters to choose from, each with their own attack styles.  The levels are fun and frantic and manage to escalate the pace without overstressing the player.  Bosses are large and impressive with the typical pattern-recognition gameplay, and each one unlocks a new character to play as.

The downsides are repetitive enemy types, enemies that can one shot you, enemies that insta-stun, and the 'Battery' system which is a poorly disguised countdown timer.  This last part was probably the most annoying aspect of the game as I prefer a very defensive style of play, but was frequently forced to 'dive' straight into large swarms of enemies in order to keep playing, despite not having taken critical damage.  It's not a deal breaker, but something to be aware of.

Still, it's fun albeit too short.  There are 5 stages which contain 5 levels...and that's it.  I didn't go into boss rush, time attack, or whatever daily quest option they've implemented...that stuff's just not for me.  It was nice being able to switch characters at the beginning of each stage instead of them having to make their own progress, but I do wish the game kept track of who cleared what.  I may have been more inclined to replay more missions.

In the end, it's a fun, pick up and play game that is definitely worth getting on sale.  I think there are better games to buy at full price, but this one is worth a spin at a lower price.

7/10

39121283.review:
Fun shooter gameplay, terrilbe design choices. You have a ticking hp that is constantly going down, bullet hell style gameplay and only one character that can be considered truly long range. What this means practically speaking: Unless you play as starch you have to stay close to enemies, so you wont have time to dodge the incoming bullets, and are under a constant time pressure every mission all game. This is insanely annoying during boss battles and takes the fun out of it as you are bound to 1 style of play throughout the game. It's also great fun that health packs have a timer until they dissapear, and spawn ON TOP of a major enemy or boss that you take damage from on impact.


Note: Hours are lower than they should be due to offline mode, I've beaten the game.

Wonderful short-but-sweet twin-stick shooter.

The idea to replace a conventional health/lives system with just hitstun and a time limit is a unique idea and works wonderfully, letting them jam-pack each level with enemies for some crazy action without making you feel overwhelmed.

The story having hints of a deeper lore is neat and makes me hopeful for a sequel, and each character having both very unique playstyles and different dialogue for each boss level lends a nice sense of replayability to what is otherwise a pretty short game.

Also, there's an unlockable first-person mode that totally messes up the balance, but it's just plain fun to play because of how silly and out-there it feels.

For me, Assault Android Cactus became the first "shoot 'em up" which I finished and I'd like to say that this is probably the best way to introduce yourself into the genre.

I learned about the game long time ago from a Steam Controller commercial and even bought it "just to check out", but after the tutorial and a few first levels my interest in it diminished, until 1 year later I decided to give it another chance. It turned out that if you get through the first zone, the game will become fun and exciting. Yes, from a side view it looks like player can get only one of three power-ups and variety of enemies is quite limited, so everything else has to be extremely boring, however the fact that the power-up changes it's function over the time and that every android has it's own play style and that developers made some specific features for each level (like, variable topology), disprove it and in reality, the game is pure fun.

Yes, it has some flaws (lacking of VO in dialogs or quite short campaign), however in my eyes, Assault Android Cactus is a well crafted project and I'd recommend it to anyone who wants to try a game in "shoot 'em up"/"bullet hell" but is being afraid to pick any.

A great twin stick shooter. Great art style with fun and diverse characters with different playstyles to suit your needs, great soundtrack and really fast paced action. Linux port is great as well (though I don't use Linux anymore due to other ports being terrible). I have only played for less than an hour as of the time of this review, but to me this is not a game that you play for hours at a time. If you are ready for a shot of adrenaline, you'll play it for 20-30 minutes. Even with such low play time, I heartily recommend this game.

I love the way the levels shift around as you move through them and just how tight and responsive the controls are and well pretty much everything about this game is awesome so just buy it and play it.

35592824.review:
Assault Android Cactus is a wolf in sheep's clothing. It may look like a cute game for kids, but beating this arcade, bullet hell, twin-stick shooter is no joke. Be prepared to be utterly destroyed when it comes to the last boss battle.

High fidelity audio and visuals paired with tight, fast gameplay make this title a fun party game not only for kids. The pushing techno beats, pew pew sound effects and lively voice acting build up this games' galvanizing, energetic mood. Due to its easily distinguishable colour cues and bright graphic effects on plain backgrounds, the game provides the visual clarity needed within a bullet hell.

Boosting the action and putting further pressure on the player is the need to keep the android's battery up. This underlines the importance of speed: the faster enemies die, the faster the next battery drop occurs. With that internalised, it's an overall easy to learn game with a manageable selection of consecutively unlocked android girls, each with their own weapon loadouts.

Different game modes, unlockable lore, art and game options and multiplayer add onto the otherwise quite short single player campaign. All in all, Assault Android Cactus is a fantastic twin-stick shooter.

There's daily high score challenges and 9 different characters to unlock who all have unique weapons and abilities.
Good stuff!

33448401.review:
A fun game, for just about everyone. It is a bit shallow, I wish there was more to do in terms of grinding, rather than chasing high scores. However, if you like things like that, then you will have no issue here. This is a game, even a player who doesn't enjoy "endless runners" (ie COD Zombies, Temple Run, etc.) Where you can just turn on and have fun with. Controller or M&Kb works fine. However, the controller is definitely the way to go to fully enjoy the game. As there isn't many buttons you can push anyways. Most buttons are not mapped to any single key. It is a twin stick shooter. If you never have played one, you simply play by aiming with the right analog, moving with the left, with a various combo of other buttons. 

This game is relatively short. It took me about 6 hours to complete. However, this does not make the game a breeze. I played the campain mostly during single player. This game is a kick ass party game, to get people together playing something. You don't have to be super good to have fun. The levels are not randomlly generated, and neither are the bosses. If you play enough, you will begin to memorize spawns. I assume playing the entire campain would be faster with more players. Please dont get this game looking for a bangin' single player. The story is a one and done. Nothing really awesome, unless you get into the characters and story. Which isn't bad either. The game does get progressively harder and harder, and as you unlock new unlockable characters, and play older levels, you will see how much better you got without even noticing! Through and through this game will make you feel good. Good fun, good story, good price, a underrated game that deserves a place is most Steam Owner's Libraries. The better the sale the better the feels. 




TLDR;

Pros:
Low PC requirements
Controller Support
Unlockable Characters
Mulitple Mode Types
Great Music
InCrEdIblE Maps, there are some really great ideas here.
Kid Friendly


Cons: 
Kinda a shallow game, can't really see anyone playing this for more than 50 hours single player.
Not recommended for single players 
Fun, but still feels a little lacking
Not enough water


I highly recommend this game, try it if you can. I really wish there was online matchmaking, but a sequel would be better!

Cheers :)

I don't see it as being a terribly attractive single player offering, so if you're likely to play this single-player, I'd skip. But with friends who are comfortable with twin stick shooters? heck yeah, it's fun!

32457156.review:
Короткая версия обзора: 
Если вам нравятся игры этого жанра, то вам почти наверняка понравится эта игра. За исключением последней пары уровней эта игра простая и доступная, сделанная в целом с явным намерением получить игру в которой максимально возможное количество людей сможет найти удовольствие.

Более длинная версия обзора:
Assault Android Cactus - доброкачественно исполненный аркадный "шутемап". Вы бегаете и вы стреляете по врагам на уровнях, пока враги не кончаться, а иногда сражаетесь с боссами. Управление отзывчива, игра работает гладко, а картинка приятна. Однако, эта игра окромя прочего делает ряд интересных вещей, о которых мне хотелось бы поговорить далее.

1. Сложность
Как было замечено в начале обзора, эта игра преимущественно простая. Как и в других играх этого жанра, игрок может получать урон, получение которого отнимает у него очки здоровья. Однако, в этой игре по окончании полоски здоровья игрока не ждет экрана Game Over, и с него не будет списано никаких жизней, ничего подобного: потребуется всего лишь провести серию кликов мыши чтобы вернуться в бой с полным здоровьем. Проигрыш здесь зависит от другой механики: Батареи. В верху экрана всегда находиться таймер-батарея длиной в минуту, по истечении которой персонаж-андроид попросту отключиться. Чтобы на дать заряду опуститься, надо собирать Батареи, которые падают раз в такое то число убитых врагов. Требования в основной игре довольно мягкие, и потом проиграть "обычные" (те. без босса) уровни довольно тяжело.

Тем не менее, это не простая игра. Или, иными словами, эта игра простая - если вы хотите её просто пройти. Как вы могли заметить, в начале обзора я назвал эту игру "аркадной", и это неспроста: как и в старых аркадах, здесь есть очки и таблицы рекордов. Они, конечно же, присутствуют во многих играх, но мало в каких они важны настолько. Если вы хотите себе вызов, сложности чтобы преодолеть, то у игры есть на это ответ: Можно попытаться пройти уровень лучше. И не абстрактно "лучше по очкам", эта игра специально предоставляет большое количество ступенек по которым можно забираться даже не оглядываясь на таблицу рекордов. А для тех, кто хочет лезть выше и выше по ступенькам сложности существует игровой режим Infinity Drive, который на время написания этого обзора прошло всего три человека (!).

Эта часть игры довольно важная для меня лично: видите ли, я не являюсь человеком который преследует счет в играх, который стал бы переигрывать уровни по много раз чтобы набраться чуточку больше очков. Но не в этот раз, эта игра сумела изменить это и позволила мне открыть другие стороны себя как игрока.

2. Уровни
Уровни этой игры короткие и быстрые, что очень важно для предыдущего пункта: переигрываются они быстро и бодро, а с уровнем роста игрока ещё быстрее и бодрее. Разработчики явно старались сделать каждый уровень уникальным: почти у каждого есть своя фишка и своя уникальная форма: так, например, на одном из уровней вас ждет вращающаяся горелка, наносящая урон и вам и врагам, а на другом уровень будет буквально генерироваться у вас под ногами, поднимая пол, стены и дыры в зависимости от того с какой волной врагов вы сражаетесь.

3. Персонажи
Ситуация с игровыми персонажами здесь напоминает ситуацию с уровнями: разработчики приложили старания чтобы они получились по-настоящему разными в плане их геймплея, и это у них удалось. Здесь вас точно не ждет ситуации с персонажами которые отличаются друг от другая тем что стреляют быстрей/медленней но слабее/сильнее. Здесь вас ждет довольно серьезное разнообразие: от простых пулеметов и вплоть до плазменных полей, черных дыр, летающих радиоуправляемых роботов, мин или даже бура, способного вбивать толстых врагов в стену и бурить насквозь. Что ещё интересней, персонажи для своего разнообразия на удивление сбалансированы: если вы зайдете и полистаете таблицу рекордов, то заметите что, хотя в ней и виднеются явные тенденции и фавориты, вершина редко полностью оккупирована одним единственным персонажем, а чуть ниже пестрит полным разнообразием (и это в аркадной игре про набор очков, попрошу заметить!). Кроме того, в сюжете персонажи выступают пусть и простыми, но приятными личностями.

4. Игра, которая хочет чтобы ты получал удовольствие
Что-то что можно проследить в предыдущих пунктах, как тему, и что то что я уже написал в короткой версии обзора: эта игра хочет чтобы ты получил удовольствие от нее. Она дает вторые шансы, дает батарейки отстающему игроку чуть быстрее чем положено, призывает рисковать, дает быстрые и веселые уровни, ступени, чтобы забирать наверх таблицы, харизматичных и разнообразных персонажей на разнообразных уровнях, и все это она делает очень естественно и органично. Во подобных играх "эффективной" тактикой было бы убегать от врагов и отстреливаться назад, бегая по периметру, меняя эту тактику силой воли, чтобы пытаться начать "играть в нее хорошо" (ни от кого не убегая и лавируя между врагами, на грани опасности). Но в этой игре нет этого большого скачка: процесс перехода от новичка к профессионалу происходит спокойно и размеренно. В эту игру не просто приятно играть, в нее приятно также и переигрывать.

Я абсолютно одобряю эту игру и крайне рад что мне довелось в нее поиграть, чего я рекомендую и вам.

31761883.review:
I did not think it was possible for twin-stick shooters to be as good as Assault Android Cactus, but AAC delivers.

AAC made a bunch of daring changes that worked to its advantage. Weapon-switch is tied to a "dodge" function, giving you a few iframes when you switch weapons. Combine that with a short regenerating health meter and you can take a few scratch bullets without it instantly ending your run (Though solid, strong hits don't cut you any slack, so play smart.). In fact, dying is not a serious impediment either, as the game relies on a "battery" timer, which you need to refill by blasting enough enemies and collecting the battery that falls out. Death costs you rank, score, time, and weapon power, but the game only ends if you cannot keep that battery timer full.

This sounds silly but it works really well. The rank system is incredibly smooth and there is enough to chaining and survival play that it doesn't matter if you're amazing, great, decent, or awful at Assault Android Cactus, you will still have fun and have something to aspire to. From just survival, to careful secondary weapon management to keep your chain, to perfect play still trying to squeeze points out of the game, AAC has something for everyone. Not to mention an infinite survival mode, too.

And the game itself? Hordes of robots on elaborate, shifting levels. As you shoot through the levels, panels flip up, paths open and close... each level almost feels like a character in the game, and it's done without being disorienting or feeling cheap either. Enemy spawns are smart so as to not impede your chains. Big bosses cap off each world, all top notch. In addition, you have nearly a dozen characters to choose from, each with different weapon sets, demanding different strategies (And all with unique story dialogue if that's your thing.). That's not even counting the unlockable cheats. Small Head Mode. First Person Mode. Alternate weapon sets. AI partners. Tackling higher player count enemy swarms by yourself. All on offer. AAC is the total package.

I never thought I would see a twin-stick shooter outdo Geometry Wars 3 in excitement or game design, but Assault Android Cactus delivers in spades. Definitely give this one a shot.

31760720.review:
A small, four legged robot fires a trio of bullets at me and I dodge, switching to my secondary weapon to gain a few brief moments of invincibility, kill him and turn to… Another small four legged robot. Who shoots me dead. Anyone who knows me can tell you that the only way I improve in a video game is through knocking my head against the proverbial brick wall. Assault Android Cactus is no different, and my first few hours are not going well. 

Developed by a small, three man studio out of Australia, Assault Android Cactus, or AAC for short, is a top down, twin stick shooter that is both difficult and extremely forgiving at the same time. Featuring twenty unique levels and five memorable bosses, it offers a good solid chunk of game play, unique maps and bosses, and online leader-boards for those who are more aptly skilled than I am. Players take control of one of eight Androids, and one secret unlock-able Android, in an attempt to make it to the end of a large space ship in order to stop a robot rebellion. Once you’ve finished with that, the game also offers a once-a-day randomized level, score hunting on those leader-boards and something called “Infinity Drive” which seems to be an endurance type game mode where enemies spawn in large numbers, and you’re expected to do your best to survive. I cannot tell you that I did well in it.

In short though, it took me about five or six hours to beat every level in the game, but it was time well spent, and I look forward to coming back to it.

Gameplay

Getting shot in the back by a treacherous, sneaky dog-robot is, in other games, a death sentence. Game over, try again, learn from your mistakes. In AAC, the devs went with a different approach. Where most games like this give you one or two hits before you game over, AAC gives you a generous health bar that can take three or four hits, and that regenerates whenever you go a period of time without getting hit at all. And, instead of lives, player Androids are given a bar at the top of the screen in the shape of a battery that continuously ticks down as you play. Every so often, killing an enemy robot drops a battery for you to pick up, extending your meter at the top and letting you continue playing. Coupling these two together results in a system that encourages you not to get hit (You obviously aren’t going to get a battery when you aren't killing things), but also rewards you when you manage to do so, and forgives you when you make a mistake. Some might call it hand holding, but I call it being kind to the player. Not everybody has lightning quick reflexes.

Speaking of reflexes though… you’re still gonna need some. Trying each of the eight Androids you can  unlock taught me a lot about myself, and how much I suck at video games. Each of them has two weapons, each unique to them and from every other character, and they all play differently. While Cactus, the lead character and the namesake of the game, is given a standard machine gun, and a short range flamethrower you need to get in close to an enemy to use. Easy to use while teaching you the basics of the game and where you can stand without getting shot, she’s the first Android you are thrust into this world with and is a good choice for beginners. Then you begin to unlock the others, and things take a turn.

I won’t describe every Android and their play style in detail, but expect to find characters who wield Railguns that penetrate, short range shotguns whose power drops off immensely with range, a gun that tracks enemies for you (not always a good thing) and a smoke covered tomboy that shoots lava. Yes, really. They each feel different from the last, and each feel as if they were designed to do different things in the game. Some seem designed to finish quickly and compete for high scores, while others seem weaker, designed perhaps to work best with a buddy in co-op. And yes, there is local co-op.

While a game like this would easily shine in online co-op, the small three man team that built this can be forgiven with taking the easier option of local only. Up to four players on a couch, or in chairs huddled around a small computer screen, can play at the same time with fun, chaotic effect. A small crown above each characters head lets you know who is doing the best at the time, but things shift quickly and getting knocked down once or twice can send the crown flying across the screen to find your buddy. Fast paced, colorful and sometimes hard to keep track of yourself, AAC toes the line of making you hate your friends and having a genuine good time because, while one person cannot finis hthe co-op version of the levels alone, having that one guy (me) who is not as good as the rest does not doom you to failure. Life, and co-op AAC, is a team game.

Graphics

Most top-down shooters struggle to make the graphical side of their game fun to look at, and with such a small team working off a limited budget, you’d expect Assault Android Cactus to do the same. Like me, you’d be wrong. While it won’t challenge games from big companies for eye candy awards, the team at Witch Beam went to painful lengths to make sure their small little game was as nice looking, and sounding as could be. From their lead animator, programmer and designer who has worked at companies such as Midway, Electronic Arts and Sega, to their Audio Director who worked with games such as Total War, Need for Speed and FIFA Soccer (throwing in a BAFTA award along the way), their passion and ability ooze from every corner.

From colorful, expressive characters to bright enemies, constantly changing levels and cute, albeit short, cut scenes there is not much you can complain about the game from a visual standpoint. Enemies are easy to pick out from the bullets, the bullets themselves are easy to find and avoid, and where some games find you lost among the chaotic battle happening around you, AAC goes to great lengths to make sure you know where you are, where the danger is, and conveys all of that in a gentle on the eyes, easy to read screen.

The one complaint I can lodge has to do with a certain dog shaped, toaster looking enemy in the game. Hopping around joyfully, these little monsters open up a hatch on their back, launching a missile up into the air where it rains down on you. A bright red marker shows you where it’s going to land with plenty of warning but, with your eyes watching the enemies around you, the floors sometimes moving on you and the game wanting your attention in seven different places at once, it’s far too easy to miss that little red circle and walk straight into a missile. Maybe that’s my mistake though? We’ll call it fifty-fifty.

Performance

This is where things get a little tricky for me to sound authoritative on. While certainly not a five thousand dollar machine, my desktop computer is designed and built to run games at a high level, and finding myself hitting 250+ fps with all settings cranked to maximum in the game is not a rare occurrence. So how can I say exactly how smooth this game runs from a technical aspect? Well, I can’t. Not entirely. But I can tell you that the game has very low minimum requirements, others I know have run it on mid-tier laptops and I, myself, have run it on my Mothers laptop, she of the “this website said I needed to download this” fame.

I’ve also found success running it on a desktop at school and, while the frame rate stuttered and struggled to stay steady at anything over 15 fps, the game did run, and on a machine I expect contained pictures of components on the inside instead of any real machinery. As long as you keep the settings reasonable, know your own machine and keep an open mind, it should run fine for you. And, hey! If you’re still worried after reading this, the game has a free demo for you to check its performance yourself. Those are still a thing some devs do!

31441168.review:
[h1]Fun local coop bullet hell game with interesting character choices.[/h1]

Assault Android Cactus is very cutesy, but don't let that fool you.  The game is fun.  It has unlockables and achievements to keep you interested in progressing through the levels and doing your best.  That said, it's frustratingly hard for the less bullet hell oriented players.  If you are familiar with bullet hell games, you know to focus on dodging bullets above all else, and that's sometimes very difficult to accomplish in this game.

Overall, it's worth the full price, but I feel like the devs could add a lot to the experience through DLC or free updates.  There's a lot of room for improvement.  I will now list the pros and cons for those who are still on-the-fence.

Pros:

[olist]
[*]Characters are very unique, giving each character its own playstyle and some room for replayability and experimenting with character abilities.
[*]Gameplay is very well balanced between bullet hell genre and coop shoot-'em-up genre.
[*]Boss fights are very challenging!
[*]The overworld map feels very much like a recent Super Mario game.  I found it very unique for this type of game.
[*]Graphics are very pleasing to the eye.  Characters look very stylish, and there's no slow-down or framerate drop even when there are tons of enemies and bullets and explosions.
[/olist]

Cons: 

[olist]
[*]Characters can't be picked solely on appearance, because the weapons and abilities are tied directly to each character.  That means you can't play as the green character and use the red character's abilities or shooting style.
[*]Difficulty doesn't scale to the amount of players, so playing with only one player or by yourself makes the game kind of frustrating.  I don't really mind the difficulty when playing by myself, but my wife hates playing without the cheat for additional AI players.  That cheat was especially useful for defeating the first boss.
[*]The game is linear and lacks any form of exploration.  I would have liked to see some branching paths on the map, perhaps making some boss fights optional but rewarding players with additional characters once they beat said bosses.
[/olist]

Again, the game's good, but it's a bullet hell game before anything else.  It's worth playing with friends when you can.  Get it at full price and show the developer some love. :)

Graficamente è pulitissimo e gradevole, ricco di colori e senza sbavature. Tantissime le modalità, che vanno dalla storia, a rush, a endless run, ognuna personalizzabile tramite altri modificatori; chi si lamenta della longevità è perché non è cresciuto nelle sale giochi ed è abituato ai videogiochi moderni, dove con titoli come questo si andava avanti a giornate intere senza alcun problema. Consigliato!

30856217.review:
I have been trying to decide what my favorite twin-stick shooter is. Tormentor X for it crazy frantic, balls to the wall gameplay? Nuclear Throne for its insane presentation, killer soundtrack, and tight mechanics? Binding of Isaac for its random craziness and replayablilty?  Monilith for upping the Isaac formula by adding faster and tighter gameplay? Nex Machina for its beauty and the desire to 100% a level at all costs? Full Mojo Rampage for is sheer visuals and difficulty or Geometey Wars 3 for....well, a lot of the above? No. After a ton of time will all the mentioned titles I decided Cactus was the winner.
  No game on my list nails everything so well. The presentation is the highest I know of in this genre. The graphics, gameplay, control, unlockable character, unlockable "mods", and flow of this game are perfect...and the music, the MUSIC.
Every unlockable character plays very diffrently from the others and changes the core mechanics. The levels are clever in their design from a sheer visual aspect, and demand revisiting just to get a high rank and a position on the leaderboards, and the infinity drives just that, a battle arena that goes on forever and keeps the high standards main game, even a daily for an added bonus.
 I know some people don't like the battery aspect ( you have to kill quicky and wait for a battery to drop to keep on playing), but this is why I chose this game over all the others. This one added element keeps the game frantic and fun. The battery system is fair. Do well and they drop at a constant pace, don't and the game becomes heart pounding experience where its a race to do better in hopes of getting a drop. This mechanic never felt cheap, and in the end made me a better player.
Being an old ass arcade gamer I love these types of games. Robotron 2048 was my favorite game as a kid, not Pac-man. I've played every twin-sticker there is. This is my overall favorite. It does so much so well. It really came down to Tomentor X ( hard mode please), and AAC. Both are extremely fun, each for thier own reasons, but Cactus won me over. One is short and mean, the other is meant for longer gaming stretches and rewards you with more than a high score. You know what? Get both. If you like these type of games you're going to want them anyways...

On the POSITIVE side almost everything about this game is awesome. The funny characters, the music, the graphics, the creative level design, and of course the boss battles are great too. So how could I thumbs down this game? 

The NEGATIVE side... The BATTERY. You want to take a very fast and intense game and make it unbareable? Add a battery to your android that lasts about 1 minute. It is an added stress to a massive pile of stress. With this unrealistic battery life the game is now perfect for gamers who are high on speed. All other players will play for about 20 to 30 minutes and quit. 
Players like intesity at their own pace. For example: Pick a shooter game, any game, you can run into the fray and fight to the death or play it safe, play smart. It is your choice. Being reckless is more intense. Playing it safe helps you live longer. You can do one or the other or both. NOW add a 1 minute bomb strapped to your chest. Your only choice now is "Run in die, restart, run in die, restart, run in die, restart..." What is the fun in that?

30745795.review:
It's hard to say more than what's already said. It's a twin stick shooter, the characters are cute, and it's really, really good. Instead, we'll address the common negative comments for the game:

"Game is too hard": there are unlockable EX options to make the game easier; they disable high scores but that shouldn't matter if your goal is to just have fun.

"Game is too hard": There are many different playable characters; if you're having trouble with one character, try another. The character you unlock first is extremely good against bosses, and against the first boss Cactus is pretty servicable. For normal stages (and the Licorice fight), Holly and Lemon are probably the easiest to handle, while characters with narrow shot patterns that don't penetrate (like Cactus) aren't quite as good. Also seriously use your secondary weapons.

"Game is too hard": I'm 35 with old man hands and a crappy trackball mouse, and I found the game a little on the easy side, since weapon switching makes you invulnerable for a really long time (probably .75 seconds).

In other words, if you see a review that claims the game is too hard, chances are that reviewer is bad at video games.

30684554.review:
ストーリーありの360度シューティング。左スティックで移動、右スティックで射撃方向制御。

敵がわらわらとわいてきて、それを片っ端から撃ち壊す爽快なゲーム。主人公の性格も破壊的であり、とにかくなんでもかんでも片っ端から壊していく。敵の種類はちょっと少ないかな？と思うが、ステージ構成は進む先々で手を変え品を変えいろいろなパターンで楽しませてくれるので飽きない。ステージが進むごとに選択できるキャラが増え、キャラの武装ごとに攻略パターンが大きく変わるのも良い。もちろん気に入ったキャラだけを使い続けてもOK。ストーリー上プレイヤーキャラは猛烈な勢いでバッテリーを消費するロボであり、どんどん敵を壊してバッテリーを回収しないとあっという間に電源が切れてゲームオーバーになってしまう。ゲーム全体を通して「スピーディーな立ち回り」を要求される。時間制限があるかわり、攻撃をうけてダウンしても一定時間すればボタン連打で復活できる仕様になっており、殲滅速度さえ基準値に達していれば何度死んでもOK。全方向シューターの中で珍しく？それなりのストーリーがあり、ボスと遭遇するときに選んでいるキャラで会話内容がかわるのが面白い。ボスにやられても別キャラを選んでリトライすると別の会話が聞けるのは面白い。とはいえ、そんなに深い、感銘を受けるような壮大で奥が深い話でもないので過度の期待は禁物。本気で遊ぶとわりと短く、もう少しボリュームがほしい。UIが日本語対応なのはGOOD

雑魚戦とボス戦の難易度のギャップが厳しい。雑魚相手の通常ステージはさくさく進んで爽快なのだが、ボス戦になると急激に難易度があがる。どのボスも固く、何度かパターン変化して攻めてくるので雑魚ステージよりはるかに手ごわい。そしてこのゲーム特有のバッテリー切れによって、うまくパターンを構築できていてもダラダラやってると即死があるのでなかなか攻略が困難。何度もリトライが必要だ。通常の雑魚ステージのサクサク簡単爽快攻略と比べると別ゲー感すら感じるギャップ。忍耐力のないカジュアルプレイヤーにはちょっとつらいレベルだと思う。お助けAIをアンロックすれば火力が上がって楽勝かと思いきや、AIがいるほうがパターン構築が難しいというジレンマ(´・ω・`)　箱コンが2つ以上あれば同時プレイもできるので友人に協力してもらったほうがいいかも。　しかしボスを倒したときは思わず「やったぜ」と口に出したくなる、昔のきつかったゲームさながらの達成感があったのでやりがい重視の人にはいいかもしれない。

アイテムは「攻撃支援ロボ」「移動速度上昇」「敵を一定時間硬直化」の3種類で出現後一定時間でほかのアイテムに変化する。通常ステージはどれをとっても役に立つが、ボス戦後半になればなるほど「敵を一定時間硬直化」するアイテムが重要で、アイテムドロップ時に最初が「敵を一定時間硬直化」のアイテムかそれ以外のアイテムかで難易度が大幅に変わる印象を受けた。どのキャラもセカンダリーウェポンがつよく、しかし当てにくいので、ボスが硬直して防御もしない、というのはこのゲームのボス戦においては重要な感じだ。

操作系に不満あり。右スティックで射撃方向を制御するが、実際射撃をするにはトリガーボタンも押さなければならず、実質トリガー押し続けながらスティックをぐりぐり倒すので指がつかれる。発射タイミングが重要なキャラもいるので、射撃方向制御と発射を別ボタンにしたのかと思うが、スティックを倒すだけでその方向に発射してくれたほうが指が疲れないし楽だ。一応トリガーを押せば方向固定でスティック操作がいらない局面はあるが、敵が全方向からやってくるわけだからそうもいかず。某ゲームとかで慣れてるとかなり不満な操作系だ。せめて操作設定でスティック倒すだけで射撃できるようにしてほしいところ。

全方向シューターが遊びたい、動画見て気になった、という人には「セールならおすすめします」って感じ。

29748166.review:
I would describe the game as a great start. 

It's a twin-stick shooter with bullet hell elements where the character shot-type design is pretty varied. It has [i]excellent[/i] animations and a camera that rather impressively captures long-ranged and/or fast abilities that most games would have trouble with. It runs on a potato and usually looks nice.

The main problems with the game are that the difficulty curve is totally ecletic, and that the bosses are very bland and uninteresting. That is a huge let-down in a genre where the bosses are usually the main attraction. The game is never particularly difficult, due to the interesting "Battery" mechanic where you can only die by failing to score a certain amount over time, instead of dying when your health depletes. I'm generally positive about this mechanic but my god does the game tend to use it as a crutch for completely negligent enemy and area design. The main source of difficulty is the sheer amount of enemies spawning at any given time, which can get very difficult to handle in stages with gimmicks. Despite the zone-based design, the difficulty of each stage appears to be totally arbitrary since in nearly all cases, smaller stages are harder than larger stages. This means that I managed to S+ rank three levels on the open-ended final zone on my first try, but I struggled to even get a C rank on a second zone level with tight corridor design and a rotating flamethrower. 

The bosses similarly seem to defy a curve. the second boss has an expanding and retracting swarm of insects protecting it with extremely little room to move once they retract on you. But the fourth boss's [i]most difficult[/i] attack is a curtain of bullets with obvious character-size holes inbetween them.

Then there is the extremely bizarre decision of having barely two frames of invulnerablility after getting hit...in a bullet hell. This is what I mean by the game using the battery mechanic as a crutch. In any other twin-stick bullet hell this would be absolutely inexcusable, but because you can never "die" as a result of the time-attack design, I can't say I'm bothered about it. Batteries are a [i]very[/i] interesting mechanic, but it's obvious that they were used here to prevent people from whining about the difficulty.

Pretty much the definition of "points for trying". I would have been much harder on the game if it wasn't an independent project.

29432614.review:
I've played this game for 25 hours as of this review, but AAC is already one of my favorite games.  It's extremely addictive, and this game caused the first time I've ever had strain in my directional key fingers in my ~25 years of PC gaming.  It was a subtle ache that felt so good because it reminded me how much fun I'd been having.

The art style is modern futuristic.  The music is pumpin' and really gets you into the game.  The sound effects are absolutely perfect.  The characters are simultaneously cute and cool in every way, and each has their own unique style.  I love them.  The simultaneously cute and cool style of this game sets it apart from any other futuristic game I've ever played.

This is a game with an example of a perfect difficulty curve.  It starts out very easy and increases in difficulty at steady rate.  It took me about 8 hours to beat the game the first time, and 4 or 5 of those hours were spent on the last boss.

While I think this game is incredibly good, there are a few minor technical flaws I encountered that I'll cover in the next few paragraphs.

I found that disabling vsync for lower input latency helped me, as their vsync implementation seems to add quite a lot of input latency.  With the frame rate I'm getting, I barely notice any tearing.  Also, the isometric camera mode makes the game a little easier for me, and I was able to start getting some very high scores using it, as it just aligns with my brain.

This game does have multiplayer, but it is local co-op only (not even LAN, unfortunately).  It does not support multiple keyboards and mice, so at least one of the players must use a gamepad.  My brother and I played it together and it was quite an enjoyable experience, but there is one major flaw with the multiplayer camera.  The camera is so zoomed in that often, one player or the other goes off the screen, making it much more difficult for that player temporarily.  I hope this is fixed in any sequels, expansions, or patches of this game.

The player character is not locked to the center of the camera, which makes mouse aiming require a bit of extra effort to know where your character is on the screen, making leading shots and close-range angles more difficult than they could be if the player was always centered.  This is an extremely minor complaint to me, but one I figured I should address in my review for completion.  The bullets are fast enough that simply mousing over most enemies gets the job done.  Obviously, this does not affect gamepad users.  I hope an option to enable a locked camera with a more distant zoom level is added, as it would make the game even more enjoyable for mouse users like me.

I am a Dvorak keyboard layout user, and I also use qwerty's ESDF key positions for movement in other games.  This game doesn't support other layouts than qwerty, unfortunately, so I had to switch my keyboard layout to qwerty.  It also doesn't support rebinding controls, but the in-game binds are only directional movement (WASD), fire weapons (LMB), and switch weapons (RMB).  I was annoyed and confused for the first few seconds of gameplay, but I switched my keyboard layout to qwerty and wasn't bothered any more.  It's not a big deal, though it would be kind of nice if it was keyboard-layout-agnostic by using keycodes instead of letters internally, like many other games do.

Overall, excellent game, and a new favorite.  I would recommend it to almost anyone.  If there was a rating system, I'd rate it 9/10, with the 1 off only being due to the small technical drawbacks I experienced.

Edit: I've now earned 100% of the achievements in this game.  This is the first game that made me want to do so, because it's so fun.  It took me 107 hours, though I was earning S+ rank on the first 18 levels with every android for a large portion of that time.

While I still love the game, I've discovered several more issues that if fixed, could really improve the game.  While I don't remember all of them, I'll describe the most bothersome one.

The player character's aim lags behind the cursor.  The crosshair cursor is already a software cursor, so it is already slightly delayed behind the mouse movement.  However, even after pointing it to the right spot, the character's gun is not pointed to the same spot if it has moved in the last frame.  This is most noticeable when playing the sniper android, Shiitake.  I will often aim directly at the enemy in the last frame before she fires, but it will fire toward the previous frame, visibly distant from the cursor, missing the shot, even though I aimed properly, myself.  This may seem minor, but it is the cause of a large portions of my shots missed.  This affects every android, but most noticeably Shiitake and Starch, as their weapons fire in straight lines with no travel time.  If a sequel or update to this game is made, I implore the developers to fix this detail.

The problem is there doesn't seem to be clear rule when the battery will be dropped. 29287733.review:
Assault Android Cactus é um SHMUP de controle duplo seguindo um dos formatos mais antigos, amados e ao mesmo tempo odiados de todos os tempos, essa é a relação de amor e ódio com jogos estilo Bullet Hell. Sendo este distribuído e desenvolvido pela Witch Beam e lançado dia 23 de setembro de 2015.
Este jogo não tem um real foco na estória, sendo que na própria descrição na steam, está limitado a dizer: “A jovem policial Cactus está fora de sua praia quando atende a um chamado de socorro e acaba presa em um cargueiro espacial danificado que está sob ataque de sua própria frota de trabalhadores-robôs. ” A estória se dá continuidade antes e depois das batalhas contra chefes, mas são diálogos simples, porém cada personagem usado tem seu dialogo próprio com o chefe, algo um tanto incomum em jogos que você pode trocar de personagem antes da fase. No caso, normalmente o que aconteceria era ter que rejogar tudo com cada personagem para pode ter acesso as estórias de cada um.
Algo que sempre é bem-vindo em jogos nesse estilo são as características de cada personagem possuindo até um armamento próprio e bem diversificado de cada um.
A gameplay é relativamente simples, desviar dos tiros e atirar de volta, mas isso não quer dizer que passar de nível seja fácil, afinal não esqueça que estamos lidando com um bullet hell aqui.
Além de enfrentar diversos adversários devemos ficar de olho na nossa bateria (parte superior central da tela) que ao passar do tempo vai se desgastando e só é possível recuperar ao pegar um item especifico de algum adversário aleatório, este item o qual é normalmente dropado uma vez por onda (certa quantidade de inimigos formam uma onda, após matar todos a onda acaba e logo começa outra), isto é facilmente percebido pois a cada termino de onda a fase muda alguns elementos, algo que pode ser considerado incrível e tira um pouco a linearidade, mesmo que talvez não fosse necessário, afinal cada fase tem em média 2 minutos e 30 segundos até cerca de 3 minutos.
O jogo também possui muitos elementos que podem estender a gameplay, pois além do modo campanha, existe os modos Raid: Infinito e Desafio diário & todos os modos possuem ranking. Sendo que o “desafio infinito” tem ondas sem limite e a cada onda que passa novos inimigos aparecem e mais complicado se torna de continuar vivo e o modo diário na verdade é apenas uma fase criada especialmente para o dia e como o jogo tem suporte para até 4 jogadores, este desafio tem modos diferentes para ser jogado, dando até 4 oportunidades para completar (uma para cada jogador a mais).
Vale ressaltar que todos os modos de jogo dão pontos, os quais podem ser usados para comprar artes conceituais, biografias – nem todas são compradas -  e modificadores chamados de EX. Esses modificadores servem para transformar por completo sua gameplay, como mudar o contraste da fase, mudar o formato dos personagens que são chibis para tamanho humanoid e até mesmo o ponto de vista, como isométrico e até mesmo primeira pessoa. 
Assault Android Cactus não é considerado um jogo para qualquer pessoa, pois existem enormes chances de se frustrar por não conseguir passar de alguma fase em especifico, principalmente por não conseguir alcançar a recarga da bateria a tempo – ela recupera apenas parte da carga. Ou quando caímos demais, nossa vida acaba e temos que retornar a jogada clicando repetidas vezes em um botão, isso também zera todos os boosters e level que conseguimos na fase, o que deixa sempre tudo mais difícil, as quedas também afetam na pontuação final. Enfim, tudo no jogo corrobora para a sua derrota e a única coisa que temos a favor é nossa habilidade que na verdade você começa a ganhar após enfrentar o primeiro chefe e então perceber que o jogo não é algo tão casual quanto parece. 
Por fim posso dizer que o jogo é incrível e que as músicas eletrônicas que são tocadas são muito mais que fantásticas e dão maior empolgação na hora de cada fase. O impressionante é o fato de não ter presenciado muitos bugs, apenas um na verdade, onde a minha arma, que na verdade é um robô, ficou preso em uma área do mapa, logo quando a fase mudou de forma e então fui obrigado a parar de “atirar” e tudo voltou ao normal & nada mais ocorreu. Então deixo minha recomendação para aqueles que gostam de desafios.

Jogo recebido exclusivamente com o intuito de realizar esta review, caso se interesse por mais, gostaríamos de convida-lo para acessar [url=gamephasis.com/] Gamephasis [/url]. Esteja ciente que o site esta escrito exclusivamente em inglês.

29193929.review:
Far & beyond the best twin-stick shooter you'll find out there, and I say that as a fan of many of them; even Geometry Wars just can't hold a candle to AAC, and the levels are the best argument you can possibly find for why handcrafted levels in the genre are a beautiful thing, and how it shouldn't be consigned to "one of those roguelike genres, yeah?".

The levels are masterfully designed.
The character mechanics are masterfully designed, and each character plays like their own entire take on the game, not just a little tweak to how you play; You will have to relearn & adjust how you approach the game entirely for the unlockable ones in particular.
The skill ceiling is immense; Completing the game in itself is a laudable achievement; Getting S-Rank, then S+.. I don't usually find score-chasing remotely appealling, and AAC is one of the few exceptions that earns it simply because the chaining mechanic is so fun & well made, and if you ever get bored, swapping characters provides an entirely new challenge to learn.

Highly recommended, absolutely adored.

29177844.review:
(reviewed after 85 hours of play on my brother’s steam account)

When a random 15$ indie game is one of the best games I've ever played…

I picked this game up casually, hoping for a fun little diversion to play with my bro to for a few days.  It looked good enough...What I got is a masterpiece I am going to sink hundreds of hours into.
————————————

Assault Android Cactus is one of those fabled relics of gaming magic.  You know, when all of the mechanics, design, gameplay, and programming all come together to achieve pure bliss; this is a game for the real, core gamer.

…Oddly, the above is perhaps partially to blame for its lack of commercial fame.  The game is not well known or played, as you can see from the leaderboards.  What will you *Will* also see is that many of the few who have picked up Cactus hold it in very high esteem.  This is a testament to the goal of the developer: A lot of time and love was put into the game to ensure the experience is as good as it could be.  It is not a game primarily made to sell.
—

AAC is a twin-stick shooting game (like geometry wars), but it is, in my opinion, the best the genre has to offer.  Unlike other twin stick shooters where you frequently must run away and back yourself into corners to survive, Cactus has the opposite mentality- You are forced to dish out as much damage and kill as many things as fast as possible by dashing headfirst into giant hordes of enemies. The reason for this is that you do not lose by dying.  You have infinite lives.  You lose by running out of battery meter, which is constantly draining as you play.  New batteries spawn after killing a certain amount of enemies, which is expertly programmed in a very in-depth way, if you are interested in that sort of information.  This means that trying to sit back and pick off enemies won’t work, not only because the battery will be too far away to recover when it appears, but also because you will not deal damage fast enough, since practically every character must get in close to the crowd to deal their damage the fastest.  The correct mentality to mastering Cactus is to be as aggressive as you can.  Think of yourself like an evil terminator android, relentlessly rushing down your foes with calculating precision.   The meta of Cactus is fine-tuning your ability to be as efficient as possible at dealing damage.

——

I could go into a lengthy discussion of what makes the mechanics and the game itself so good, but no one wants to read through all of that.  
——

Cactus experience #1:  Trying to S+ a level with Shi itake (sniper character) on a level with escalator floors and changeable walls.  Zipping around at high speed, twirling (a dodge mechanic) through moshes and waves of crawlers, drones, bullets, bombs, rockets, drones, bees, lasers etc. while dropping mines before I lose my kill chain, picking off multiple enemies at once by lining up my shots to snipe the edges of enemy hitboxes while dashing atop escalators and around cover, chaining power ups so I can stay afloat while also trying to kill everything as quick as possible…All at the same time...Losing literally 100+ times (never stops being fun) but pushing harder and harder to be my best.  It is mad, sweaty gaming zen.

Cactus experience #2: Playing on endless mode (infinity drive) with my brother and trying to coordinate attack patterns and coordinating the effects of our different androids’ primary and secondary weapons.  Changing our tactics on the fly while racking up 800 kill streaks, while the frame rate blazes along at 140 fps. shooting and rushing down, blowing everything up, and sucking everything into a black whole as the level and music continues to warp and bend before our battery runs out.  

Cactus experience #3: Trying to complete each level on VPC4 (virtual player count 4), which basically scales enemy spawns as if 4 people are playing, yet you are by yourself.  Being swarmed by impossible odds, yet strategically thinking your way to victory, by choosing the right android and figuring out just the right strategy for the level’s specific challenges.  It’s like a puzzle.  And yet, even though it acts as a puzzle game, you are challenged by a high need for skill as well as a high ability to adapt, since you can’t completely rely on memorizing enemy patterns.  You can’t perfectly predict all of the enemy spawns and power ups, so you must be able to shoot and think on your feet in addition to planning ahead.  

Cactus experience #4: Earning #1 in daily drive (daily score chase mode) CO-OP, only to realize no one plays this game, then being sharked by 200,000 points right before the day ends.  

Cactus experience #5: watching the best players speed run levels and the campaign in awe.

Cactus experience #6: Being mindblown at how geniusly programmed the following are: The game is impossibly fun and balanced no matter whether you’re playing solo or up to 3 buddies or 3 AI partners…There is challenge for the casual gamer all the way to the hardest of hardcore, without ever compromising the core metagame!  There’s a variety of challenges to shake up the meta and keep you going for hundreds of hours. Every one of the 9 droids has insane potential and very different play styles, yet are all balanced and excel under varying situations.  Some droids are very friendly to those who aren't the best at aiming, while some characters demand nothing less than perfection.
———————


Verdict: if any of this sounds remotely intriguing, pick this up or try the demo.  Do you live for the edge of your seat, hands sweating, heart pounding feeling when you can feel yourself on the verge of beating an impossible challenge?  Are you craving a bat-sh*t insane, high octane arcade game that requires a staggering amount of skill, concentration and strategic thinking?  If so, just buy this and thank me later.  
  This is a game to master, and with 9 droids to master for every stage and changeable play conditions/challenges, an infinity mode that is literally near impossible to beat, and daily score challenges, you can easily sink hundreds of hours into this game either alone or with friends as a party type game.   Oh, and good luck trying to S+ every level with every droid... But can you do it on VPC2-4?

Negatives: I wish the campaign was slightly longer (a few more levels to master)….it’s just too f***ing good, especially with how much variety and originality is in the stages, whether it’s on a moving train car or a giant convection oven with changing heat patterns.  I also wish the UI was slightly better designed.  It isn’t necessary to look at the UI during intense moments, but it would be nice if it were quicker to read.  The audio cues for certain situations should also have been explained to the player.  Basically, you will hear things like dings and chimes to notify the player of recharging health etc.  It can be really useful to pay attention to.

Bonus: the soundtrack is also very good and crazy and will get you in the zen mode and pump up your jams.  You’re gonna need to be in that zone.  

9.5/10  (I don’t give high scores lightly)

So, Assault Andriod Cactus is a game that I can see myself playing for at least another 40 hours, if not more.

It's very polished, has more than enough of a campaign (getting to the last level takes about 6 hours, but I have yet to beat the final boss), and then revisting the levels to try and S+ or get good scores on them is fun, as it's very satisfying to beat a level with an unbroken chain of kills. I also enjoy the characters of each of the andriods, even though they aren't 100% voice acted (which would have been fun, but it doesn't get in the way of the game)

If you like twin-stick shooters at all, you *really* need to pick this up.

28964441.review:
A challenging and rewarding twin stick shooter that's a blast to play coop.  The unlockable android characters are well done, and I feel like the level design and bosses push you towards utilizing different androids.  There are a lot of really enjoyable levels with a nice amount of variance and some callbacks to Bomberman stages.  Sometimes the huge numbers of swarming enemies are a bit much, and the hot floor level is a bit ridiculous, but those are minor gripes in a very enjoyable shooter.  

Some of the voice acting is a little bland, but with the energetic techno and sounds of your weapons cover them up well.  When your battery runs out and you have to restart the level, do yourself a favor and listen to the song they play.  It's got to be the longest "you died" song in any video game, but it's darkly amusing and always gives me a chuckle.  

One of the reasons I bought this is because it's on Linux.  Thanks devs for porting it over, the game is a good fit for SteamOS.  I had trouble getting my Steam controller to work like an actual controller instead of a mouse and keyboard, but I also have been experiencing some other annoying controller issues after an OS update so YMMV.  XB360 controllers worked great.  

After beating the game make sure to use those credits you earned to unlock stuff in the store.  There's also a final android unlocked for your second playthrough along with a boss mode.  The android character playstyle design is very well done, with a fun mix of different styles and some imaginative weapons.  It would be nice if there was a little bit more info on what their abilities do, as some are not obvious from the select screen.  A power and range meter would be cool too.  

Even so, this game is a lot of fun.  It was about a 6-7 hour experience for me which feels just about right for the $15 price tag.  The boss battles are old school pattern memorization affairs, that feel a little unfair until you learn the fight and then breeze right through it.  A little tip, switching your weapon gives a half-second of invulnerability for dodging some of those bullet-hell style barrages.  

The level designs, android playstyle designs, and overall polish of this game make it for a great time with a buddy or three.  The game scales with the number of players, and you can even unlock a buddy AI if you're a solo player wanting to see the screen filled with death bots.  If you're even a little interested, buy this game and phone a friend.

28935568.review:
Alors c'est quoi ce jeu qui parle de cactus avec un smartphone en plein assaut sur le central 13 (A voir absolument en passant) ?

Un twin stick shooter avec une règle simple : Tout ce qui bouge, tire doit être détruit seul ou à plusieurs (4 au max). Un tir principal et un tir secondaire puissant mais limité qui se recharge quand on ne l'utilise pas. 9 personnages jouables dont 4 jouables directement et 5 déblocables en ayant battu les boss (au nombre de 5, évidemment).

Bof encore un shoot en arène sans intérêt ? Et non, les arènes sont dynamiques et aucune ne se ressemble créant ainsi un rythme frénétique aux joutes contre les méchants robots. 
Ajouez à cela une batterie qui se décharge au fur et à mesure et impossible de chercher à temporiser en courant comme un âne autour de l'arène. En effet, la mort n'est pas punitive dans le jeu même si matraquer le bouton fait perdre un temps précieux. Seule la batterie entrainera le game over, mais les développeurs ont pensé à tout : les ennemis lâchent de quoi la recharger.

Et les boss sont vilains pas beaux ? Pour être tout à fait honnête, le boss de fin est le seul qui peut poser un réel problème et encore, dans sa dernière phase. Une petite tape sur les doigts pour les développeurs de ne pas avoir mis un petit checkpoint avec celle-ci parce qu'elle est difficile avec son timing ultra serré et tout recommencer du début est pénible par le temps passé.
Les phases de boss deviennent du shoot them up assez réussis et j'ai beaucoup aimé Venom (Meilleur boss du jeu et de loin).

Et les personnages jouables, tous différents ? Oui et c'est une bonne idée sur le papier d'avoir créé 9 personnages qui n'ont pas les mêmes aptitudes et certains (Aubergine pour ne pas la citer) sont très difficiles à manier alors que d'autres sont un peu fumés ( Strach en tête). Après, c'est à chacun de voir le style qu'il préfère même si certains permettent de flinguer les boss facilement.

Les 25 niveaux se parcourent très rapidement : 3H pour boucler le mode histoire. A noter qu'il y a un mode infini, des trucs à débloquer avec de la monnaie gagnée en jeu (Pas de microtransactions) et une dimension scoring omniprésente (Chapeau à ceux qui ont débloqué les rangs S+ dans les niveaux).


En résumé, c'est un excellent twin stick shooter qui fait le job avec des arènes dynamiques, des ennemis intéressants même si j'aurais préféré que le surnombre ne soit pas la seule mécanique pour augmenter la difficulté, l'idée de la batterie qui se décharge. 
Le plus gros défaut hormis la durée de vie (Très relative dans le sens où la dimension scoring l'explose pour peu que l'on s'y investisse), la direction artistique est ultra générique. Un peu plus de folie aurait été appréciable.

I've been looking forward to this one based on the fact that I love this genre (top down arena shooters) more than just about any other game. I'm prrreeeettty decent at them just by virtue of having played almost all of them that I've ever come across because I'm a moron, which also gives me a little bit of authority to make judgment calls on the genre. It's a hit and miss style of game for most people and I've slogged my way through some super shitty ones but I can say with all honesty that this one lives up to its reputation as one of the best.

It's kind of off putting at first because of how cutesy everything is, but the cutesy takes a back seat pretty quickly and then it's just balls to the wall enemies and explosions and death. The arenas change as you progress through the level and there are mandatory pickups that drop after certain waves of enemies to keep you constantly moving and ensure there's never really a lull to the action.

In addition, there are several characters to play as, each with different weapon/superweapons, and a different combat feel for each. On top of that, there are a number of pickups that you can grab, each of which is supremely helpful and add a level of tactics to the game because you can wait for the pickup type to cycle through (a la Raiden, if that means anything to you) in order to maximize your damage or control the crowd.

I got it in a bundle, but I'd honestly recommend it to just about anyone who is into the genre for sure, and anyone who thrives on almost completely mindless action as well

28657069.review:
Well, that went by fast.

Assault Android Cactus is, as you might already gather, a twin-stick arcade-styled shooter. Move with left stick, aim with right stick, shoot with right trigger, switch to secondary weapon with left trigger, and your secondary weapon has cooldown. There are eight androids to play all with rather different sets of weapons, four to start, another four to unlock. You fight pretty generic robots, then there are bosses.

It's not complicated, but it's very well done. Since it's not a space shooter (well, it's in space, but aboard a space-ship, and- you get the idea) it uses space well, often shifting the battle and offering new impediments, like pits or walls or hazards. (You can't fall.) It's often shifting what robots you're facing or how the battlefields work - it goes to some lengths to change the environment around you, even if it's mostly pretty standard industrial interiors and exteriors. Still, levels never feel truly the same. Some are wide-open, some are confident, some have gimmick traps- I felt like at no point was it retreading itself. Which it better not, at its basic length of a few hours to beat the main campaign. It has leaderboards survival, and optional cheats and modes to encourage you to try and play to perfection.

There are some small disappointments. The leaderboards aren't divided by character, since some androids are more suited to some levels in others, and knowing you were the best with an oddball android with a spinning sawblade or a drill attack would be good to know. Though the walking speed is generally fast enough, at times I felt that it was just a hair too slow to readily escape attack patterns I hadn't already anticipated. And some of the bosses can be overly harsh compared to the rest of the game - one in particular hits with a swarm of robots that in one attack pattern I still have no idea how certain androids are supposed to deal with it without losing a life.

Assault Android Cactus mostly just an example of how to take a classic game style and just polish it until it feels great. There's something intangible here, but circling around robots, hosing them down, singling out stronger robots to engage with missles or cannonballs, it all feels very satisfying. The characters are very basic but appealing. The story is... generic but at least not intrusive in its genericness. The continue mechanic is clever in how it subtly allows score attackers to give up at a point of failure but allow everybody else to truck on to victory without feeling like they actually failed. Ultimately, if you're in the market for a twin-stick shooter with a fun charm to it, this'll do you. It's probably the best I've played since Waves, and that's solid praise as far as I'm concerned.

28542006.review:
[h1] Summary [/h1]

Assault Android Cactus is a top down twin stick shooter.

+ Very addicting
+ Smooth gameplay without FPS limits
+ Challenging
+ Pleasant music
+ Interesting different character personalities and gameplay styles
+ Attention to detail (e.g., each character has a different speech on each boss, dedicated music to the game over, lots of extras)
+ Replayable
+ Good voice actors
- Characters could have been better designed, i.e., they're good but I think the artist can do even better perhaps in the next game
- Sometimes it is hard to distinguish bullets, mines, lasers and such

[h1] Review [/h1]

In this game you control an android that must destroy every robot on each level. It is a top down shooter that can be controlled with either mouse and keyboard or with the analog sticks of the controller.

The only way for you to lose in this game is if your battery runs out. If your health goes to zero you just have to get up by taping your fire button. Batteries are used with time even if you don't shoot. To restore your energy you must get new batteries, which are dropped by one particular robot in each wave. So time is the most important factor in this game.

There are many characters in this game and each character has different weapons. All characters carry two weapons. The primary weapon does not have any limitations, you can fire non stop until the level ends. The secondary weapon is usually more powerful but requires some time until you can fire again. Each character has it's own advantages and disadvantages. You can choose whatever character you want in each level at any given time and in some cases a character is better than another in a particular level. All characters also have very distinct personalities, making the game more interesting.

Sometimes power-ups are dropped. There are three kinds of power-ups: tiny robots, pretty wings and blue circles. Tiny robots gives you more fire power, pretty wings makes you faster and blue circles stop every robot in screen for a limited amount of time. The power-up item changes to another power-up every few seconds. The order is always the same. If you get the same item twice, the time is extended.

There are also bosses in each section. The bosses are easy to understand but hard to defeat. As usual the bosses work with patterns. A small but welcome detail is that each boss has a different speech for each character you choose and in this way you can figure out the story of the characters.

The game does not have any FPS limitations and works very well in my 144hz monitor. Altough the models and textures aren't very detailed the game looks very good and there is a lot of variation in each level. The music never gets in your way and in fact it is pleasant to hear. The voice actors are very good and give character to each android.

Overall I enjoyed this game a lot but I have two minor issues, mostly personal opinion. The character design seems to be an attempt at chibby style 3D models but look more like bobble head action figures. The models look okay but Î think they could be better. In fact my favorite is Starsh because she's the one that looks less of a bobble head. That and the extras that she's easy to control and the funniest one. The other is that it is very hard to notice some things because the coloring is not distinguishable enough. These kinds of games usually have very bright bullets so that the player can notice them. While the bullets are bright in this game they're still easy to miss in my opinion.

After you beat the game you have some options. Option one is to beat each level in campaign with score S+. To do it you need to kill every robot in a single link and at a reasonable short amount of time. For bosses you just need to kill the boss fast enough. Another option is to beat the boss rush more, where you defeat all bosses in a row. The infinity mode is simillar but before beating the bosses you need to kill all robots that show up. Finally you can try to beat the score of other online players.

I recommend this game for anyone who wants a challenging and fun top down shooter.

28476383.review:
I don't usually play shooters, but when I do, it's Assault Android Cactus ;)

This is really an amazing game. The character design is cute, and they have voice overs and dialogue lines to match. The controls are quite smooth in terms of moving your android around the map and aiming to shoot. If you have a Steam controller, I highly suggest downloading my custom control template where the trackpads do all the work as your thumbs simply hover over them, no button presses required! Well maybe except for self revival and weapon switching, but still a lot f stress of them gaming muscles.

It may get hectic from time to time with tons of enemies crowding the screen and a bunch of projectiles coming your way, but it's a blast trying to navigate the well constructed levels while also learning enemy properties all on the fly. This game forces you to pay attention to everything on screen, especially your battery. If it runs out, it's gameover. You can keep on "dying," and you can revive yourself, but the level isn't over until your battery fully runs out, so keep on an eye on that and how much you shoot. Aimless shooting will cost you your battery, so be careful and be present. If you blink, you die! If you think about anything else, you die! So pay attention.

I highly recommend this game at either full price or a significant discount. You can't go wrong with it if you want to practice making your brain really really focus on some serious hand eye coordination. If someone like me who doesn't usually like FPS or any other shooters, can love this game to bits, that's saying a lot.

28319741.review:
Story is mostly just background to set up the scene (though there are some developments near the end), visuals and sound are good enough. You can use either controller or mouse and keyboard for single player/local co-op.

You choose from selection of characters (four initially, one more for each boss you clear to a total of nine), each with their own primary and secondary fire. Secondary fire is usually more powerful but has a cooldown period in between uses. Different characters do better in different situations.

Powerups are dropped after defeating some enemies. They include temporary firepower boost, enemy freeze, and movement speed and I believe they cycle if you don't pick it up right away.

Battery is just a timer on how long you have to complete the level. Your battery always drains but as you kill enemies they sometimes drop battery powerups that refill the battery a bit.

There are five zones and six bosses. The regular stages were pretty standard and forgettable but I enjoyed the boss fights. The later bosses are sometimes like a bullet hell lite because they sometimes spray the traditional screen-filling bullet patterns but it's very managable compared to other bullet hells.

It was nice for me because when you get hit enough times and die you can continue (losing score and battery life) so I didn't really get stuck on a level. The way you lose is if you don't defeat enough enemies in time or let a battery powerup despawn (usually because you waste time while respawning) and run out of battery.

Worth a try if you like the idea of bullet hells/shoot em' ups but aren't at the skill level/don't have the patience to do hardcore ones.

Other thoughts:
[list]
[*] Nice that it has a codex, unlockable character art, game play modifiers (first person camera, graphics theme changes, etc.), sound test.
[*] Nice that it has campaign, boss rush, endless (score attack), and daily (score attack) modes.
[*] I liked to circle strafe fire around the arena, it felt like it was important to keep moving. When things get crowded it approaches the level of a bullet hell though the fact you don't die in one hit makes it bearable (I was never skilled enough to beat the true bullet hell games). Respawning here doesn't interrupt the flow of battle (no wasting time on a death animation and continue screen) because the only way to really lose is by running out of time (battery).
[/list]
