28279988.review:
I didnt expect much when I picked this game up at a really cheap price. From what I saw in screenshots and videos, the presentation didnt appeal to me at all, the story seemed really uninteresting, and the aestethic of it all simply didnt mesh well with me. All of those things remain true even after I have beaten the game.
However, that in no way should be an excuse to miss out on this, because what I didnt expect to find here was a videogame.
And when I say videogame, I mean it in the rawest and most primitive sense possible that the term implies.
This is the kind of game that leaves your hands sweating and your eyes glued to the screen in the hopes that you dont miss a single moment of action.
Assault Android Cactus is a twin stick shooter, where the goal is to kill every enemy in each stage of the game. Thats it. Thats all you do here, the "story" it presents is just an excuse to give some sort of context for the player to get back into the action, and besides shooting enemies, there really isnt much else for you to do here.
And thats why this game is so great. It has no pretenses about what it is, and it uses its genre to full effect to give you one of the best arcade experiences in the last few years.
Every stage is a frenetic chase to the end goal, with the screen filling with impossible levels of enemies and bullets while you do your best to avoid it all and stay alive for as long as you can, and every arena introduces a unique layout to shake things up, from floors disappearing when you step on them, to laser beams moving across the screen at certain intervals and making you run for cover just in time.
The game also introduces a brilliant game mechanic where your character has a battery that depletes as time goes by and that can only be charged back by killing a certain number of enemies. This means you can never play it safe and stick to a corner waiting for enemies to come at you, as you will have to chase them at numerous times during the game just to get that recharge before you run out and fail the stage. This is what makes the game unique among other similar titles, as it provides alot of entertaining stressful moments where you are running against time as you throw yourself at every enemy just to get a goddamn recharge.
The game has a huge list of characters to pick from, each with their own unique weapons and skills, so the game never gets stale, and gives ample room for experimentation and player preference.
It also comes with bosses, and they all significantly ramp the difficulty up with creative attack patterns and alternate forms, the Final Boss being one of the highlights of the game.
Soundtrack is amazing and perfect for this game, with one of the best Game Over tracks  I have heard in a long time, that alone is worth losing a stage on purpose.
So yeah, if you truly like engaging videogames  that actually demand the player's effort and attention, then please give this a chance, it truly deserves more love than it gets right now.  
And who knows, you might actually like the characters and story more than I do

28270640.review:
TL;DR: Probably the best twinstick shooter ever made. Why are you even looking at this review? Play the [b]free demo[/b] and then buy the full game when you inevitably love it.

[h1]The good[/h1]

[list]
    [*] It's a blast, plain and simple. Blowing up robots with the various weapons, powering up your weapon, dodging bullets, lasers and mines, stacking up immense combos and multikills... there is a lot of classic arcade twinstick action to be had here. 
    [*] There are 9 playable characters to choose from, each with really unique weapons. No two characters play alike. 
    [*] It looks and feels great, especially for an indie title. Models, animations and textures are on point. Controls are simple, tight, and responsive.
    [*] The electronica soundtrack is fantastic and has exactly the right mood. I usually don't value soundtrack that highly but this one is exceptional. 
    [*] All of the levels are awesome, and the bosses are all unique and have their own identity. 
    [*] The skill floor is pretty low, and the ceiling is wicked high. There is a lot to be learned and achieved before you can say you've mastered this game. I'm hundreds of hours in and I definitely haven't. 
    [*] They don't labor you with cutscenes, but there is an interesting backstory if you care to look for it. 
    [*] Kind of a minor one, but the achievements are interesting. For some of them, part of the challenge is actually figuring out how to accomplish them first. For example, there's an achievement for getting a chain of 1000, but no one campaign level has 1000 enemies in it. 
[/list] 

[h1]The bad (kinda)[/h1]

[list]
    [*] It's an arcade game at heart. That means most of the replay value comes from replaying levels to get the best ranks, to shoot for the highest possible score, and to get the shortest completion times (there is an active 
[url=speedrun.com/aac]speedrun board[/url] !). If that's not your thing, this game is going to be about a 5-hour experience for you. I don't see this as a downside, but a lot of people do, and this review is here for your benefit, not mine. 
    [*] No rebindable controls. I don't have any problem with the control scheme, but if you plan to play with KB+M with an alternative layout like Dvorak or AZERTY, you're going to need a workaround like AutoHotkey. 
    [*] No online play. More a lack of a positive than a negative, but it's important to know. Cactus is primarily a singleplayer experience and online play was too costly to implement. If you have an Nvidia card and a strong upload speed, you can work around it with [url=http://moonlight-stream.com]moonlight-stream[/url]. 
[/list] 

[h1]Stuff that other reviews say is bad, but actually isn't[/h1]

I looked through the negative steam reviews to find some common objections. God, there is some stupid stuff in there. For your sanity, please don't read them... 

[list]
    [*] "It's a time attack game". Well, yes and no. The failure condition is time-based, and beating a level fast is rewarded, but it's not a speedrunning game at its core. There is a more interesting scoring system which gives rise to other ways to score high. The fastest runs are very, very rarely the highest scoring. 
    [*] "The characters aren't balanced." They're not supposed to be. They're balanced in the sense that you can get an S+ rank on every level and boss with every character if you try. Some characters are easier to play, some are better for speed and survivability, others are better for scoring. The highest scoring characters are also the ones that require the most skill to use, they're not noob tubes. Some characters are better for crowds while others excel at boss busting. 
    [*] "The battery is a bad system, lives or health would be better". Never understood this one. There's never any reasoning to back it up whatsoever, nor is an alternative system ever properly outlined. The battery is a great system, I don't see anything wrong with it. How would lives or health work in multiplayer, anyway? (Badly is the answer). 
    [*] "You need to memorize every spawn to play well." Lol no.
    [*] "The final boss is too hard." I don't agree personally, it seems appropriately hard for the final boss of an arcade game, but devs listened to this sentiment and nerfed it recently by a little bit. If you're struggling with any boss or level, you can ask the community for advice.
    [*] "Getting knocked down is too punishing." It isn't. You drop lots of weapon power pickups on knockdown, your secondary weapon is unaffected, and you push away mobs and have temporary invincibility on wakeup. The game gives you lots of ways to work around knockdowns. 
    [*] "It's not very casual friendly". Alright, this one is fair enough, I suppose. It is an arcade game that requires developing some skill, and there's no easy mode, but it's not some hardcore ultra hard l33t game either. If you're a very casual player, you're not the target audience and thus this game might not be for you. 
[/list] 

So yeah, try it out. I love it, I think you will too!

[h1]Obligatory shilling[/h1]

[url=https://discord.gg/kSyaZk6]AAC Community Discord[/url]

[url=https://assaultandroidcactus.miraheze.org/wiki/Main_Page]AAC fanwiki (Miraheze)[/url]

[url=http://www.speedrun.com/aac]AAC Speedrun Leaderboards[/url]

[url=https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC1y9jbn7VezoS8Kad7f2EzQ]My YT channel[/url] where I post a ton of speed/scoreruns

28217010.review:
If you like Robotron 2084 or Smash TV and love shooting at TONS of enemies, then this is another great game in the same vein! Assault Android Cactus is a twin-stick shooter in which you are the title character Cactus (or one of her 8 Android companions, when you unlock them all) attempting to stop the Section Lords on an impossibly large spaceship from planning to destroy the universe or something. 

The plot is not that important, but it does have some funny dialogue and cute characters, so that's a plus. Graphically, the game is actually pretty impressive, and it can get quite hectic with the multi-colored enemies and different types of projectiles all on screen at once. Just as well, the game supports up to 4 player Local Co-Op, which is an absolute blast to play with anybody who will join you on this bullet fiesta. (Sadly no onlie multiplayer, but I understand why the devs couldn't implement it).

The gameplay is the star of the show, here, and it MORE than fulfills the desire of anyone who enjoys these types of games. Not only is there a wide variety of distinct characters to play with,  each with primary and secondary weapons, but there's so much replayability for score chasers with the rating system. Not many games have convinced me to play for so long just to make my score a *little* bit better, but with the addictive gameplay and skill-based rating system, this game inspired me.

There's plenty of replyability with the EX modes you can unlock for the campagin, finishing each stages with every character, AND Daily Challenges and a Boss Rush mode. This is a game that is ABSOLUTELY worth the price point with all the polish and content on display here.

I'll give it a 10/10. Assault Android Cactus is a perfect example of a modern entry in the twin-stick shooter genre done right. It's difficult, but it'll hook ya for sure.

I will review all my humble bundle games and see which is worth playing and which is not! Like a lot of people i buy H.B. games as a pack because i want some of the games, but not all. I will play for 5 minutes (or a little bit more) and give you my opinion on it. Sometimes the game will surprise me, sometimes it will be a total disappointment. Just keep in mind this is my opinion only and is not an objective view of the game. You might actually like it!

The review will be constructed into 5 parts:
1. Game description (from what I’ve seen in the time I’ve played).
2. Did i finish the game (YES/NO/Maybe in the future) and why.
3. Pros/Cons.
4. Final thoughts.
5. Rating

So let's begin...

1. Game description:

A fun top-down shooter with nice colors and nice diversity between characters.  It gets a little bit hard after a while and it would have been nice to select which weapons you want, as oppose to them being set for each character. It also gets kinda repetitive after the first few levels. A difficulty adjustment setting would have been nice.
2. Did i finish the game? NO/ Maybe in the future

The story is almost nonexistent, but in this type of games there is no need to be. All that it is is a fun distraction after a hard day at work.

3. Pros/Cons.

PROS:
-Great colors and visuals
- Easy to understand controls

CONS:
- No difficulty setting
- Gets repetitive after a while. 

4. Final thoughts:
Not a huge fan of top-down shooters, but this game made me want to play more, until I’ve died 7 times on the same level and rage quit. If you like this kind of game, get it!
5. Rating

6,5/10

28179699.review:
Assault Android Cactus is a fantastic twin-stick area shooter. 

With its innovative battery system that replaces the usual life count system, it allows for an easier access to beginner of the genre. Meanwhile, the scoring system and the leaderboards will offer worthy goals to pursue for both veterans (getting S+ ranks on all levels) and experts (getting on top of the leaderboards) of twin-stick shooters.

Moreover, the many levels of the campaign offer varied challenge that keeps each level unique and fresh. Moving platforms, night sections and environmental hazards are only some of the problems you will have to face.

Finally, the large cast of characters, each with their own weapon and special weapon, enriches the game further. First, because the small storyline and funny dialogs of each character makes the game charming, and give it some soul. Second, because it allows you to switch your playstyle depending on your preference, your skill level, or your scoring objective, making the game more enjoyable and more replayable.

Frankly, there is nothing bad I can say about Assault Android Cactus, it's a great game, that manages to strike the balance correctly between accessibility and challenge, and is fun and rewarding to play.

27974681.review:
Assault Android Cactus is a very enjoyable twin-stick shooter with some fun mechanics. The story is pretty simple: a gigantic space cargo ship has been seized by a super AI gone rogue. A special space police force known as 'Assault Androids' send in their cop 'Cactus' who happend to be nearby to stop the AI from keeping the ship hostage. Unfortunately the ship is divided in large different area's who are all controlled by other robotic section lords who also have gone rogue. You're going to have to fight your way through the different levels to get to the core of the ship and put an end to the mutiny!

There is a large selection of characters to play with that you gradually unlock. The difference in gameplay per android is quite considerable. You don't need to worry about ammo for special attacks, instead there is a cooldown for special moves. 

An interesting mechanic is your battery. This game doesn't work with continues but once the battery depletes, it's game over. Enemies will drop batteries throughout the fight and you'll have to collect them to keep going. If you get hit multiple times, you go down and you'll have to tap yourself back to life, at the cost of battery power. No matter how many times you get knocked down, as long if you have battery power you are good to go.

There is a fun combo system that revolves around chaining enemy kills. Once you killed an enemy, a counter shows up with a timer in the shape of a circle around it. You need to kill another enemy within the time limit to keep the chain going. You get a ranking based on your combo chain. Breaking the chain will end up in not managing to get the highest ranking for the level. 

Other than batteries enemies will drop power-ups that give you temporarily boosts, such as extra speed, firepower assistence or freezing enemies in their tracks. They can help you a lot if you're in a pinch. 

If you're a fan of twin-stick shooters this is a very, very enjoyable purchase. It feels refreshing to play and is also fun in couch co-op.

I only have a handful of hours in this game, but if you're a fan of top-down twin-stick shooters or shmups, this is definitely worth your time. The single-player campaign's level design is such that the learning curve is gradual and the S+ goals are achievable. Every new mechanic introduced gets utilized as you discover them, which makes the later levels difficult but understandably so, given the skills you've picked up along the way. 

The fact that RNG is not a factor also makes this a worthwhile addition to your library. Everything that happens, every enemy that spawns (excepting the Daily and Infiinity Drive modes) is because of your play style, not some random twiddling of bits inside your computer.

The soundtrack is almost reason enough to pick this up. Award-winning composer Jeff Van Dyck has put together a score and soundtrack that suits and enhances the frenetic play style. His sounds are the only positive in a failed run.

If you don't love this game, I'm confident you haven't played enough.

27657393.review:
Assault Android Cactus is awesome. It's... just awesome.

The graphics are awesome. Although the super deformed look of the protagonists is a tiiny bit cringey, the animations and the personality of every character more than makes up for it. The levels are colorful and everything's perfectly identifiable despite the intense chaos that usually clutters the screen. GUI is clear and immediate, and there's a lot of detail put into the game's appearance. Shield emitters will change colors depending on your current level, shell casings will spray everywhere, lighting effects look great, and it keeps a mostly solid 60 FPS throughout.

The sound is AWESOME. The OST is catchy and upbeat, with a lot of really kickass tunes. Voice acting is cool and the sound cues are always present and identifiable. Honestly one of the best sound designs I've heard in a while.

The gameplay is awesome. The controls are a *tad* awkward since the right stick is a bit overly sensitive and being used to TBoI having to constantly aim in 360º takes a bit to get used to, but it is otherwise very fluid and fun. There is no death (you only get knocked out) and the core of the gameplay consists in killing enough enemies to spawn a battery in order to keep the timer up -a battery takes 60 secs to deplete-, resulting in a very fast paced kill-a-thon. There's a lot of enemies that can knock you out in one hit but also power-ups that help in staying mobile or killing the enemies faster. All enemies are easily identifiable and all have cues for their attacks. It feels awesome zipping around the battlefield taking out high priority targets while lasers fly everywhere.

The characters are awesome. Although they have just a couple of lines they have distinct personalities and a very different feel to them. The weapons are sort of expected but very varied and sometimes rather original, especially on the unlockable androids. Each one will have different lines on the bosses, helping replayability, and all are viable to get e throughout the game, although some will work better than the others. Overall though, they're really franchise worthy, they're that good.

The bosses are... well, on the one hand they are pretty awesome because they are bullet hell stages that feel super satisfying when you get to beat them, but on the other they can become really annoying and frustrating if you're not carrying a character that works well against them.

The play value is awesome. Every stage is pretty easy to beat, but there are ranks to them where you'll compete against your Steam friends and put on a global leaderboard as well. There's also Daily Drives and the Infinity Drive mode, which takes place on an ever shifting arena. It's really impressive to see it change shape and completely alter its mechanics Layer after Layer. You really won't get tired of it any time soon, and for the price it's going, it's a real value. There's 5 levels per stage plus one boss, and 5 stages total. After beating the game you get Boss Rush, *and* there's several unlockables that you can buy with credits which add filters, change the camera POV, give you super alternate weapons, and so on.

Assault Android Cactus checks all the boxes for a *great* game. Memorable characters, unlockables that keep you going, amazing soundtrack, great graphics, easy to get in and hard to master and polished-to-a-shine gameplay really makes it a title worth playing. The bosses can be a bit of a bitch, and you'll always end up wishing for a whole campaign more, but that's the problem with good games, they eventually have to finish. For a 3 people team, this is an outstanding achievement, and truly a twinstick fan's wet dream. 9.5/10.

27349207.review:
Assault Android Cactus caught me off guard. It was a game I bought from Humble Bundle, and I only now got around to it.

It's actually a extremely solid game of it's kind. A rather "safe" twin stick Bullet Hell.

What I mean is, unlike any other like this that I know of, taking hits won't end in immediate gameover. Instead, your true life bar drains over time, and when you take enough hits in a row in a short time, you'll topple over and shut down. You'll have to smash the fire buttons to revitalize your systems and get back to the fray. A battery in the top-middle of the screen will drain constantly, without pause. You'll have to be killing enemies by the packs constantly to spawn powerups, and the battery which is VITAL to your progress and survival.

The levels are all unique in every way. While 25 levels may seem like a lazy number, it's far from that. They truely affect the gameplay and force you to fight smarter, rather than harder. Do not expect easy victories. For those addicted, there's even Daily Drives and Infinite Drive. Daily Drives are daily levels, as expected on the tin. Infinite Drive goes on forever, until you can no longer support your android.

The characters you get to play as all cater to different styles, which is a fantastic plus. From snipers to shotguns, railguns and magma launchers, this is perfect for anyone. In fact...

One of the best things about the game is that it's 100% multiplayer friendly, allowing you to have up to four players in the mayhem. Sadly, there's no online co-op, which would've been a nice addition.

One of the things that I was surprised about is the story. This game didn't even need a story, and I assumed it didn't have one to begin with. I was wrong, and pleasantly wrong. It's not a big story, and I like the implementation. Bossfights give you good insight into the story of the characters, and there's even bios you can look into if you really want more.

The bosses are quite worthy of their position, ready to absolutely destroy players. They all have several phases and are a lot of fun to fight.

Just don't expect the game to be easy. The music is mostly techno, and is alright in my opinion.

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

While I struggle to reccomend this at a full purchase, anything 10$ and below, you will get your money's worth!

26989281.review:
This game is just a ton of fun to play!The 9 different androids all play pretty differently and make it a blast to replay levels and try out different strategies. Plus they're all really cute and full of personality! The level design is great and is constantly changing things up or throwing new surprises at you. All of them are different and have really cool visual theming too, since each one is a different section of the ship the game takes place on, like hydroponics or freight zones. The music is some awesome EDM and it really gets you pumped to blow up robots, and keeps you going when you lose and retry.

I also really like the battery mechanic, where your battery constantly drains and you have to kill enemies to get more recharges before it drains down and you die. It fits so well into the core loop of shooting and dodging enemies and their bullets, and succeeds in making a bullet hell type of game that is really freindly while still giving a great level of challenge. It also makes the action, which is already fast-paced and relentless as hell, even more tense when you're on the verge of running out and are fighting extra hard to find that one enemy holding the recharge.

Also the boss battles are great and it has a whole bunch of neat extra modes and mutators. And local co-op multiplayer!! My girlfriend and I played through a bunch together and its a really fun way to play since you share a battery meter and have to watch out for each other.

Overall this game is a ton of fun and extremely worth the money. It is a phenomenally smooth and exciting fast action game and bursting with heart and personality. Go play it!!!

This game is pretty fun but the scoring system can be somewhat strange.  Risky moves like dodging enemy attacks at the right moment or grazing bullets have no impact on the score.  Precise aiming and completing levels without taking damage also do not affect the score.  Instead the game puts an extremely strange emphasis on enemy prioritization which results in completely counterintuitive and awkward strategies in order to place well in the leaderboards.  When you finally do get a "good" score you won't feel like you played "well" - instead you feel like you just followed the game's arbitrary scoring rules more closely.

Play the game for the spectacle and perhaps for the daily drive, but don't hang around to climb the leaderboards.

Great visuals, cute characters, great voice acting, an -awesome- game over song, and some pretty good gameplay for the most part can be found in this game. I expected to play it 30 minutes, be bored to tears, then come here and trash the game. However, I found myself playing for a few hours all the way to the final boss fight. It was tough at times, but the aforementioned good stuff kept me going. The second to last battle nearly caused me to rage quit, but I figured out a trick since an enemy was stealing my battery charges: just kill the enemies close to me so I always got the charges. 

The final boss, on the other hand? I tried somewhere between 30 minutes and an hour out of my 3.4 hours of playtime on that one boss, in a dozen or so attempts, but to no avail. I even did a search for tips online, and found out there were basically in-game "cheats" you could buy with the credits you acquire from playing through the game, so I blew a ton of them on some "mega weapons," and I did just as badly (if not worse) than before.

What's worse, it's not one of those multi-tiered boss battles where you get a checkpoint after each part of the boss; oh no, instead, I have to fight the multiple really easy phases of the boss every time I try, despite it being an utter waste of my gaming time, since a checkpoint or separate level could remedy this, but the developers instead elected to make me "fight" (not time into, but not effort) the same parts of the boss I've dealt with easily time and again.

This boss battle has made my experience aggravating, to the extent that I cannot recommend this game.

26568917.review:
I got Assault Android Cactus with the latest humble bundle, so rather cheap. However this isn't to say that I wouldn't pay RRP for it given the chance now. 

The main campaign is about 3 hours along, and extremely exciting. The difficulty curve in this game is just about the right area, and it gets progressively challenging, with the final 3 / 4 levels giving you the anger which would make you want to rip your hair out. Naturally when you complete it you get a massive sense of achievement just from the final 2 levels alone. 

 For the campaign, it is around 3 hours. There isn't much narrative to look into here, just a standard 2 stick shooter arcade game. Due to the mechanics in the game being solid, the lack of narrative does not harm whatsoever. The characters are only in the game to add some charm, there is nothing there to make you attached to them, you could have made this game with rather primitive shapes and I would still be giving it the same positive review I am now. 

 The soundtrack can feel repetitive in places, but each zone has its own different style of music. 
 
 The game does have a lot to offer when it comes to the replayability scale, it offers you new characters as you play throughout, all of which with their own unique pro's, con's and playstyles, you could do a run through with each character. After the main campaign you also unlock boss mode, there is a variety of game modes and collectables to keep you going, if you enjoy the game enough. 

 For me, the 3 hours I spent in campaign were very refreshing after taking a back seat with games recently, and due to having a job, the 3 hours is good for now, and I'm happy with being able to pick up this game in the future. 

 If you like a challenge, and good gameplay with some difficulty, definately a must have. Would give it a solid 8/10.

它的功能是提供至多三个AI队友。
仍然可以解锁关卡，获得金币，获得成就，但是不能上高分榜（然而本来也上不了）。
在4人小队下，小怪的数量会变成四倍，BOSS血量也会变成4倍，神符的数量也会变成4倍。
但是，游戏难度却因此大大降低了！

首先是所有的怪物都会被AI吸引仇恨。
AI特别喜欢去近战位，所以只要有一个AI活着，你就可以完美输出（当然AOE还是要躲）。
然后，AI会帮你捡电池！
一般来说被怪物围着的电池，你要么干看着，要么拖尸体去捡。但是AI可以代替你拖尸体，你依然活着开心的输出
同理适用于蓝BUFF，电脑拖尸体帮你捡蓝BUFF，你开大站桩输出的简直要笑开花了。

最后，AI的唯一一个缺点，就是默认抢符，你根本抢不过AI。
电脑是宁可抢到之后秒死然后浪费掉，也要拼了老命抢你这个符。所以也就蓝BUFF有用点。
3-1一共掉了20+个符我就特么吃到一个。

26497702.review:
Fun twin stick shooter a la Geometry Wars.
I'm not a fan of the art style, but everything else is top notch :

The levels are well designed, and varied. 

At first glance, the gameplay seems standard for a twin stick shooter : shoot everything and avoid being hit. But there's a little more to it. You have a dodge and a secondary weapon. Your secondary weapon has a cool down and activating it makes the character dodge projectiles and enemies. So you have to is strategicaly.

You also have some kind of regenerating health. So getting hit once in a while is not the end of the world. You don't have to restart everytime you get hit. You won't get a good score though. So that make this game easy to pick up but hard to master.

If like games like Geometry Wars, you'll like this one.

26492566.review:
In Assault Android Cactus geht es nicht, wie der Name vermuten ließe um ein kampfwütiges Smartphone mit Googles bekanntem Betriebssystem, sondern um Cactus. Cactus ist auch keine Pflanze mit Wassermangel, sondern ein Kampfroboter, der aussieht wie ein kleines Mädchen. Also alles vollkommen normal. Und wie das so üblich ist, arbeitetet die Maschinen- Lollita des Todes bei der intergalaktischen Polizeiorganisation, deren Aufgabe es ist, bösen Robotern den Arm des Gesetzes zu vermitteln……….MIT LASERN UND FLAMMENWERFERN. Eines Tages fängt unsere dezent minderjährig aussehende Protagonistin einen Notruf ab und eilt zur Hilfe. Sie entdeckt ein, für die Story vollkommen belangloses, gigantisches Raumschiff. Nach einer wirklich eindrucksvollen und professionellen Landung freundet Cactus sich mit den Bord – Roboter…….Slaven? …….Kellnerinnen?.........Mit anderen viel zu jung aussehenden Roboterladys an. Diese sind im Vergleich zu Vorschul- Terminator 1 nicht ganz so erpicht darauf, sich von Drohnen, RobotodesKugeln und Riesenhaften Bots, den Ölwechselrückstand aus dem Körper ballern zu lassen. ……………….weil sie ich zitiere „so schwach“ sind. Sie schießen sich Cactus dennoch an, weil -----Obstkuchen. 
Kommen wir zum eigentlichen Spiel: Man wählt zwischen Lollita-Brutalo- Bot 1, 2, 3 und 4 aus, um sich anschließend durch das Schiff zu schießen. Dabei durchqueren die Kleinkind- Kampfmaschinen 5 Abschnitte des Schiffes, an deren Ende immer ein Endboss steht. Zu den anfänglichen 4 Teenie- Terminatorn gesellen sich bis zu 5 weitere hinzu, 1 pro abgeschlossene Zone. Die Level sind dabei spielerisch immer gleich aufgebaut: Ihr fallt mit eurem Baby- Todes – Bot auf die Fresse – und rappelt euch auf, anschließend werdet ihr von Fliegenden, laufenden, stehenden und auch rollenden Robotern zu Tode gehetzt. Neben dem nur bedingt Hirntoten Storymodus, gibt es in Assault Android Cactus auch noch einen täglich zufallsgenerierten Arschlochkurs, der sich alle 24 Stunden resetet und neu aufbaut. UND die wohl größte Stärke des Spiels : einen Endlos Modus, der für das was er ist, einfach scheißabwechslungreich ist.
Natürlich kann unsere minderjährige Hobbysprengmeisterin auch ihre „schwachen“ Kameraden Terminators zur Hilfe holen. In dem Chaosreichen COOP- Modus schießt ihr die bösen Roboter Bastarde mit bis zu 4 Freunden in Stücke. Grobe Stücke. Wie in Leberwurst.
Nun , das Spiel ist trotz allem nicht perfekt. Die Story kommt gerade so an das atemberaubende Plotlastige Gameplay der 2D Super Marios heran und das Balancing ist, vor allem in Bezug auf Cactus Kampfkraft alles andere als Perfekt. Mal ehrlich, DER NERD ist abartig stark. Das sollte nicht so sein. Auch die Abwechslung hält sich bis auf ein paar Giga- Blechdosen wirklich in Grenzen.
Trotz allem ist Assault Android Cactus für mich das etwas bessere, farbenfrohere und vor allem schnellere The Binding of Isaac, auch wenn es keine absurd blutigen Item- Combos gibt. Das Spiel macht Spaß wie sau und mit ein paar Kumpels könnt ihr Im Couch Multiplayer auch echt eine verdammt gute Zeit haben. Mit den Lollita- Robo- Rambos macht ihr nichts falsch.

26482799.review:
"Twin-Stick Shooter" is a genre that doesn't often interest me.  But there's a level of polish to this experience; well thought out player (of which there's multiple choices yielding different weapon and power-up options) enemy and level design, balance, and big boss encounters that reminds me of a AAA Title released on hardware from the late 90's.  It's a Playstation1/N64 era title, brought into the modern day.  The gameplay isn't contemporary, it's a dated concept, but what it does, it does exceptionally well; and it's great fun to play by yourself and even better with a mate.

Highly recommend getting hold of this if you are looking for a fun arcade experience.

26466498.review:
The good is all there: great audio and visuals, pleasant to look at and getting one pumped, the fantastic feeling of most weapons and satisfaction brought by the mayhem. Creative and dynamic levels that are stimulating by asking the player to adjust on the fly, similarly creative bosses that switch things around quite fast. So, how can I not recommend this game?

Because it is plagued with the most atrocious design flaws it possibly could've been, that is why. If you want a tl;dr, I will say this: easily the most frustrating game I played in a long time, seemingly dedicated to obsessive masochistic OCD perfectionists. Deeper explanation below.

The battery/revive system is interesting, but my god why did the idea of weapon dropping to null power whenever you die make it to the campaign is beyond me. In all the score-focused modes, yes, keep that in. But the campaign is the whole different story, there are many bottleneck places in the levels where if you die (and they are hard moments) you are fucked. Because now you need to somehow clean up this hard part with severely diminished firepower, which leads to more deaths. On top of the fact that lowered firepower makes it quite hard to catch up with killing, which is needed to refill the damned battery. This becomes even most absurd in the boss fights which are, for the most part, quite tight timing-wise, on top of being extremely stingy with orbs that you can actually pick up. And no picking up == no weapon powering up. 

An additional problem with the bosses is that the battery refills usually spawn right at the point where they stood when the phase of the fight ended, so usually right behind the boss. Retrieving these is often paramount to suicide, and since batteries disappear in time... yeah, enjoy.

The health bar could almost not be there, really. The game has an unhealthy obsession with one-hit deaths (and we already established how much going down hurts) and will throw them at the player all the time. This is coupled very annoyingly with how ridiculous the terrain can get; while enemies generally provide visual feedback to when they will strike, the terrain can be very subtle with when it wants to kill you, leading to many frustrating deaths. Also, bonus points here for the terrain spewing enemies out with no warning right onto your face. Especially when some of them blow up. Instant death if you didn't restart the map X times to finally understand what and when happens.
But there is one thing that adds an insult to the injury and it is the nonexistent post-hit invincibility. Doesn't matter that your character has several hit points, if there is a cluster of bullets coming at you, failing to dodge it will just outright kill you. A favourite thing on the bosses, they weave real rich patterns of bullets, one wrong step and you are dead. The second boss is the most sadistic here, requiring strong weaponry to deal with an absurd amount of adds that she summons while being deviously adept at killing the player right when her third phase triggers. The swarm of little flies will just ram into you and drain your health in a second or two.

All of the stuff presented above wouldn't be as fun as it is without yet another thing that just makes me shake my head in disbelief. And it is a catastrophic lack of visual clarity. The game is flashy and visually noisy like a glittery Twilight vampire, and it can lead to easy demise. When I said the health bar could almost not be there, I neglected to mention some humanitarian enemies that actually shoot stray bullets. Which, for reasons unknown to me, are smaller than every other bullet, including yours. It is possible to get randomly hit with something just because amidst all of these explosions and spray of your own weapon, something will hit you. And pray it is not a rocket. You see, some enemies shoot a rocket into the sky, and it will fall down on a designated location. And instakill you. Would be fair, it is delayed, there is a targeting reticle indicating where that will happen. So why for the love of god it is the least flashy, most dimmed and blurred thing in the entire game? On some arenas, it is more subtle than the actual environmental lighting. Just astounding, really.

As an added complaint, the devs didn't bother to design stages in a way that makes sure each of them is reasonably doable with each and every of the long list of characters offered to the players. Sure, if you grind for long enough, you will become the god of Cactus and master every character in every stage, but this is exactly the overarching problem with this game.

It is not considerate of anybody but mad perfectionists who will time the sparse invincibility frames down to a millisecond, and learn how to get through each level without dying once. People who won't be deterred by hundreds of re-tries of boss fights. In a great many cases, the game demands such an obnoxious level of perfection just to get through the damned stage without cursing all of the creation while hammering the revive button (absolutely pointless that you need to do that, btw, and just fuels the anger) that it is simply not worth the nerves. I am going to beat this, as of writing this review I am nearly done, but I won't lie: enjoyment was rare, frustration and annoyance ruled.

26466444.review: Awesome game if you are looking for a nice coop shared screend shooter(stam controllers).

26463239.review:
Thumbs up, but barely. 

+Great graphic design, clean presentation, just a slick high polished vibe all around
+Voice acting is entertaining (but minimal, which is also good)
+Nice variety of androids to choose from with different main and secondary weapons (plus unlockables)
+Doesnt overstay its welcome with a campaign that lasts about 3-4 hours with optional co-op
+Credits you earn after each stage let you buy artwork and other unlockables and enhancers for gameplay
+The ending is short but kinda funny. Oh, and "PINEAPPLE". I laughed so hard after i unlocked Starch, (maybe you will too!)

-No difficulty selection
-Only three powerups- speed up, extra firepower, and freeze enemies. These only last a few seconds though.
-The life bar is small and hard to see. Plus if you get hit too many times you get "knocked out". So you basically have to revive yourself by mashing the fire button which seems kind of pointless and kills the fast pacing. It's also difficult to tell *when* you get hit too. A large easy to see life bar with number of lives would make more sense.
-At the same time there is a battery level meter (a timer) and if *that* meter drops its game over. So there's this hectic frenzy to hope and pray that en enemy drops a green battery pack so you can keep playing, all while trying to not get hit so you dont have to keep reviving yourself over and over and losing your powered up main weapon too
-The main weapon upgrades only last until you get "knocked out". 
-The credits mentioned earlier are a cool edition but like i said id rather use those to buy permanent upgrades and have the extra artwork, modes, and other goodies unlocked through beating bosses, levels, and getting a certain number of kills and whatnot. 
-If im using the right stick to aim i would expect to automatically shoot in that direction. Having to hold the RT button to shoot just doesnt make sense to me.

6.5 pineapples out of 10. 

PINEAPPLE! :)

26440632.review:
***FIRST THING YOU SHOULD DO IS TURN ON 'INVERSE' FIRE IN ACCESSILITY OPTIONS. If you are looking for 'auto-fire,' you will never find it because 'inverse fire' is what the devs decided to call it here. Your trigger finger will thank me later***

This is a well-made game, but I would say not perfect. The art and general gameplay are all superb and fast-paced. The bosses will make you think about your approach and challenge you (except for the final boss, which I think is flawed, so it's hard because of that). The life system works off of small shield and disabling your character if you take too much damage. You're really battling the clock because your android runs out of life the longer you are playing each level. Take too long between battery recharge pickups and it's game over. It's good to see the options for unlockables WITHIN THE GAME and not as DLC, which gives this arcade-y title an old school feel.

Now, the final boss. Waaaaaay too hard. The second phase removes battery pick-ups and it's INCREDIBLY challenging to deal enough damage to survive without your battery running out. My go-to for bosses was often Coral because of high shotgun damage. Even with her, I was one second or less away from dying when I beat the last boss/phase. This is not counting the dozen or so times I came within 3-4 blocks of winning and ran out of battery due to the way the final boss phase is designed. Introducing a fractional recharge from enemies would have been useful (aka, as long as you are fighting and not disabled, you will be able to survive to the end. This way if you get hit too much, it can still be GAME OVER).

26373477.review:
Assault Android Cactus è un arcade shooter che fonde istinto e abilità in una cosa sola.

La grafica è MOLTO piacevole; sia per quanto la varietà dei livelli; sia per la differenziazione dei vari mostri/boss.

La giocabilità è ottima: semplice, veloce e ben fatta.

In tutto, avremo a disposizione 9 personaggi, ognuno con una sua arma e una sua abilità specifica; spesso e volentieri la scelta del personaggio sarà dettata semplicemente dal nostro stile di gioco.

25 livelli differenti su cui mettere alla prova le nostre abilità genocide + una modalità infinita e un'altra in Rush. Con questo prodotto avremo la possibilità di giocare in coop fino a 4 amici (no online). Come ultima cosa, ma non meno importante; avremo a disposizione delle "chicche" sbloccabili tramite i punti/soldi guadagnati dopo ogni livello; esse concernono: impostazioni di gioco per la prima persona, effetti visivi durante la partita, potenziamenti speciali, ecc.

Personalmente, ho trovato questo gioco BELLISSIMO e DIVERTENTISSIMO, dall'inizio all'inizio; no, non ho scritto male, ho scritto proprio "dall'inizio all'inizio"...
Il perchè è semplice: E' un prodotto realmente ben fatto e ben sviluppato, divertente, simpatico, facilmente giocabile e contenente un livello di sfida non eccessivo, ma, la vera pecca per me è una: la longevità; difatti è un gioco pressochè CORTO, completato dopo circa 3 ore di gioco e molto sinceramente ci sono rimasto anche male; per me quelle 3 ore di gioco erano solo l'antipasto...

Mi sarei aspettato come minimo altre 10 ore di svago e invece mi sono ritrovato a completarlo dopo quelle 3 ore ed ho continuato a giocarlo con le altre modalità + feature nelle altre 2 ore di gioco, dopodichè mi è venuto a noia.

Per me è un gioco che vale assolutamente la pena giocare; perchè è divertente e intrattiene il giocatore nel vero senso della parola; quando lo si gioca, difficilmente ci si riesce a staccare; ma dopo averlo completato, non c'è quel qualcosa che continui a tenere il giocatore incollato allo schermo.

Mi sarebbe di conseguenza piaciuto aver a disposizione più livelli giocabili e soprattutto perchè no, anche una coop online invece di un semplice splitscreen.

In finale, resta un gioco CONSIGLIATO, 
Voto = 7/10

Assault Android Cactus is a fantastic Twin Stick Shooter with tons of variety in the characters, playstyles, stage designs and extra unlockables (such as Concept Art and Codex's, to game changing gameplay options).

Featuring a 25 stage long campaign featuring unique stages and bosses, Daily Challenges to compare to the rest of the world, an Infinity Mode to test how long you can last against the endless hordes and a Boss Rush mode which is exactly what it sounds like.

You can select between 9 different characters (4 from start, the rest though the course of the campaign), all with their own different personalities as well as weapons and playstyles that vary your playstyle greatly.

Easy to learn, hard to master at it's finest in twin stick shooty games.

26249963.review:
Non, définitivement NON. Le jeu pourrait être sympa, c'est du twin stick shooter avec une direction artistique simplement immonde mais ça reste du twin stick shooter sympa dans son approche. Chaque arène offre un petit chalenge qui se renouvelle constamment: la lumière se coupe, la salle change de forme, la caméra s'emballe, des tapis roulants t'entrainent là où tu ne veux pas aller ... nan, y'a des idées et chaque arène se joue (en théorie) avec beaucoup de plaisir.

Seulement ça, c'est tout ce qu'il y'a: des arènes avec des idées. Sans ça, c'est du twin stick shooter avec une horrible absence de retour ... les vagues d’ennemis se comptent en centaines, on abat du monstre mécanique à la chaine (y'a même un compteur de combo), mais il n'y a AUCUN feeling de puissance. La faute aux bruitages qui manquent de patate, à la direction artistique dégueulasse tendance choupi-kawaï-je n'utilise que des couleurs sans nuance pour que tu ne vois rien, une vitesse de déplacement assez rapide, une hit box des plus curieuses et une lisibilité des plus approximatives. 

L'absence de feeling est un énorme défaut dans un jeu qui se veut court et à run (c'est pensé pour faire des cessions courtes, deux-trois minutes pour une arène et basta), quand tu te fais chier pendant une arène tu n'as pas exactement envie de la refaire pour améliorer ton score ... même si elle est courte. Mais il n'y a pas que ça comme souci.

Le jeu à un système (très con) d'upgrade: tu butes des ennemis, ils lâchent des petites boulettes, tu les ramasses et tu remplis une jauge de puissance. Quand la jauge de puissance est pleine tu gagnes un rang d'arme (ton arme fait plus de dégâts). Seulement quand tu "tombes dans les pommes" (j'y reviens) tu perds tes boulettes et de fait ton arme redevient un pistolet à petits pois. Donc non seulement le feeling n'est pas là mais en prime il n'y a même pas la sensation de devenir plus puissant puisqu'il faut toujours tout recommencer: le flingue tout pouwwi, ramasser les boulettes pour avoir un flingue pas trop ridicule, rince and repeat à chaque arène ... c'est chiant comme boucle, et lassant très rapidement.

Quand je parle de "tomber dans les pommes" c'est pour parler de la jauge de vie: encore un système bien con. Au lieu d'avoir une barre de vie classique il y'a une jauge d'énergie: elle se vide au fil du temps ET quand tu te fais toucher. Quand elle est vidée tu es mort, fin de partie. Mais quand tu te fais trop toucher tu tombes seulement dans les pommes: foncer dans les balles/coups n'est pas intrinsèquement mortel. La barre de d'énergie ne suffi pas pour durer sur tout une arène, donc il y'aura de temps en temps une batterie qui sera lâchée par un monstre pour recharger la dite jauge et pouvoir continuer ... ça n'a pas l'air comme ça, mais c'est vraiment con comme idée. Le principe est de t'obliger à bouger pour ramasser la batterie, donc d'avoir un jeu nerveux qui t'oblige à bouger pour ramasser tous les power ups ... ouais mais camarade t'oublies un truc: DANS UN TWIN STICK SHOOTER TU PASSES TON TEMPS A BOUGER CONNARD ! C'EST LE PRINCIPE DE BASE DU GENRE ! Y'avait pas besoin de ton système débile qui n'apporte mécaniquement rien et qui fait profondément chier puisque l'ennemi le plus dangereux est en fait ta barre d'énergie qui se vide, pas les monstres qui arrivent par dizaines ... c'est pas une idée de génie ça ? Avoir un TWS où ce ne sont pas les ennemis à buter qui sont les ennemis à surveiller ... 

Je signale au passage que devoir marteler la gâchette de tir pour se relever quand tu viens de tomber dans les pommes est purement exaspérant ...

En fait ceci doit aussi jouer dans l'absence de feeling, le but du jeu est de ramasser les batteries et d'éviter les balles que quelques monstres tirent vers toi ... c'est pas un vrai twin stick shooter, c'est pas vraiment du bullet hell (trop peu choses à esquiver), le cul entre deux chaises le bonhomme.

Comme défaut purement "game design à la rue" il faut aussi souligner les boss particulièrement stupides/insipides. Comme j'ai dit le but du jeu est d'avoir quelque chose de rapide, où tu passes ton temps à esquiver des dizaines de monstres pour ramasser des batteries/power up ... 

Bien, alors partant de ça, il faut m'expliquer qui est l'abruti profond qui s'est dit "notre concept de jeu c'est ça, alors pour les boss on va faire EXACTEMENT L'INVERSE ! \o/ " ? Parce qu'avoir un gigantesque sac à point de vie que tu vas mettre des plombes à tuer (merci le flingue de base pourri que tu ne pourras pas augmenter avec les boulettes puisqu'il n'y a personne à tuer ^^ ) qui se divise en plusieurs phases (l'aberration de game design qui emmerde le monde vidéo-ludique depuis la première utilisation de cette idée qui n'aurait jamais dû voir le jour) toutes aussi chiantes les unes que les autres (quelle surprise, comme les centaines de jeu qui ont essayé avant celui ci ...), c'est la goute d'eau qui fait tomber la pierre qui roule ... nan, ça fini de t'endormir en fait. C'est simplement pas fun à jouer, il n'y a AUCUN plaisir à les buter, et ils sont surtout incroyablement à coté du concept du jeu. 

Au final c'est donc un jeu lassant/pas amusant/pas motivant. Il y'a un système de point à gagner pour débloquer des petits bonus: des filtres visuels, un mode multi avec des bots (pourquoi c'est pas disponible d'entrée de jeu ça ? Ha oui, parce que la caméra avec plusieurs joueurs est terriblement catastrophique et fini de détruire la lisibilité de l'action en s'éloignant d'environ 14 kilomètres quand les deux joueurs s'éloignent l'un de l'autre), des têtes de taille normale (ça aussi ça devrait être disponible de base, ça rend le jeu moins moche) mais là non plus il n'y a rien de transcendant. Comble de la bêtise d'ailleurs le multi est uniquement local ...

Nan, vraiment, c'est un petit jeu à petit prix mais il ne vaut vraiment pas grand chose ...

25916232.review:
Controlli ben fatti, varietà di personaggi, arcade fino al midollo, boss impegnativi, e tante, TANTISSIME cose a schermo. 
Il tutto in uno "twin stick shooter", branca dei più famosi Shoot 'em up. 
All'inizio di ogni livello si potrà scegliere una delle 9 nostre eroine (se sbloccate) queste divergono per (ovviamente) lo stile grafico dei personaggi ma, soprattutto, per le armi. 
Ogni eroina avrà a disposizioni 2 "armi". Una pesante, che solitamente necessita di un recupero una volta usata, e una leggera, per il "fuoco d'ordinanza".
Queste ultime possono essere upgradate fino a 3 volte raccogliendo i "resti" dei robottoni da noi uccisi. Ogni livello è fine a se stesso, quindi ogni volta l'arma si upgraderà, ma al livello successivo partiremo con la nostra arma "scarsetta" per arrivare nelle fasi più concitate con l'arma ben "pompata".
Le armi si depotenzieranno anche quando verremo messi KO.
Ma il KO non sarà la fine del livello! Ci potremo rialzare e combattere anche dopo essere stati stesi. 
Il Game Over sarà quando la nostra "Batteria" si scaricherà, rendendo il gioco molto frenetico e sempre alla ricerca di nuove ricariche per la batteria, a suon di robot nemici uccisi.
Per gli amanti degli arcade, o i perfezionisti (come me) questo gioco presenta una sfida continua. Non basterà uccidere tutti i nemici senza venir messi KO per ottenere un buon punteggio, bensì bisognerà ucciderli tutti in una unica catena. 
Più la catena avanza, più il tempo tra una uccisione e l'altra dovrà essere ravvicinato, fino ad arrivare al paradosso di ringraziare quando i nemici a schermo sono tantissimi, così da cercare di non perdere la catena raggiunta con fatica. 
Nel gioco sono presenti anche gli spawn di 3 power up, dopo l'uccisione di determinati nemici:
1)Due robottini che temporaneamente ci aiuteranno con maggiore potenza di fuoco
2)Una maggiore velocità temporanea unita ad un magnetismo che ci farà raccogliere pezzi di robot e (eventualmente) ricariche per la batteria (ma non attireremo altri power up se presenti nel campo, ma dovremmo "raccoglierli manualmente")
3)Uno shot down che ferma temporaneamente i nemici a terra dandoci un bonus di danno verso quest'ultimi. 

Il gioco è vario e non lascia niente al caso. Finire i livelli ad S+ raramente è una "fortunata casualità" ma richiede studio degli spawn nemici, tempistiche, coordinazione e tanta, tanta, tanta, TANTA pazienza.
Se vi piace il genere, e gli sparatutto isometrici colorati, travolgenti ed esplosivi, questo è senza dubbio il gioco per voi!!

+     丰富的地图与系统

        AAC的故事模式里提供了超过20张各具特色的地图，8名可选人物，3 种地图画风，2套人物模型，3种摄像机视角，每名人物一套额外的重武器以及机器人队友/对手选项。

+     macbook i5 低压 的核显可以流畅玩

=    合适的配乐，战斗节奏与讨喜的 画风（个人向）

-     默认摄像机的诡异移动轨迹（除此之外EX option里的第一人称摄像机如果买了游戏请务必去试一下【和善的微笑.jpg】）

-     一些AI偶尔会被墙卡主不动导致清版困难

-     想要全成就十分困难

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

再介绍一下玩法，

你的角色拥有一定的血量，以及一块一分钟续航的电池，在续航时间内，角色死亡可以复活，不过会有时间和分数惩罚。

游戏提供三种模式：故事模式（分为普通关卡和boss关卡），无限模式和boss rush。

关卡内根据阶段（boss或者 一批小怪）确定游戏进程，击杀该阶段内的某一个敌人即可掉落绿色的续命电池包，捡起即可补充能量。

每个关卡都有独立的评分，这里直接贴S+评分的条件：1，角色不能死亡 2，关卡内全连锁（连锁：击杀敌人后的5秒内再次击杀敌人则累积一个连锁） 3，在固定时间内通关（每关时间不一样）

奶牛关：https://cowlevel.net/game/Assault_Android_Cactus/review/1951810

25574097.review:
Do you love video games? If you don't have this game, you sure don't.

Assault Android Cactus is one of the most enjoyable games I've played in a long time. A phenomenal love letter to arcade shooters that's bursting with unique qualities. It's easy to pick up and play, but hard to master. This is the quality of great games. I've absolutely fallen in love with it and became addicted.

It's hard to imagine that a small handful of people have created such a beautiful, charming, polished, engaging, and just plain joyful product. If there's one game you absolutely need in your library, it's this one. Forget the AAA walking simulators, and treat yourself right. It's a steal at full price.

AAC is a twin stick shooter where you play as androids. There's a lot of characters to choose from and each one has unique weapons and shooting patterns. You'll want to play them all since they're not just for looks, but actually play completely differently. There's a play style for just about anyone, and plenty of options for breaking out of your comfort zone.

The goal is to survive to the end of each level and fight the bosses of each world. Go to town dodging enemy attacks, power up your weapon, finding batteries to keep you going, collect temporary power-ups, and shooting everything in your path. There's dozens of enemies, every level has a unique concept, and each boss has several phases and unique attacks.

All these small things will overwhelm and keep you on your toes at all times. You will die, and it will be fun. You'll actually have to gain some skill, learn some things, and improve to beat the levels.

The real challenge is getting S+ on every single level though. To do that, you must keep the chain meter going and defeat every enemy without it breaking. Incredibly challenging and you'll keep coming back again and again to try it. The game even features an option to reset the level automatically when the chain breaks.

The game is challenging, but the average player can beat it with persistence. S+ ranks will involve quite a bit of optional skill.

The game has a lot of unlockable bonuses and extras ranging from vanity to cheat like options. You'll have to play a lot to unlock them all. If you play normally and are really into the game, you won't have to grind for them. This leads to a well balanced stream of enticement while playing the game.

The game could run on a toaster, and it supports unlocked framerate, making it not only play better, but a great showcase for a high refresh rate monitor, as any decent hardware can max out its potential.

It supports local cooperative play with up to 4 players simultaneously and scales the difficulty depending how many users play.

It isn't perfect, but nothing is. There's some minor quibbles that will lead to some unfortunate or frustrating deaths. The camera can be wonky with how it frames the action, and it can be difficult to tell where missiles will land when the screen is loaded with enemies, but you'll have so much fun, that even after you die, you'll say one more time. The short and easy to easy to digest levels make it easy to keep coming back.

The game hasn't sold well, so this is definitely a game that needs more support. You can easily put in 50 hours into the game, and there's a ton of quality content in it. Grab it right now.

25451654.review:
What a great, charming game!

Even if you aren't a fan of bullet hell games, the game still allows you to get through without too many problems.  However for the more hardcore, there is a good challenge in trying to S+ rank every level.  I haven't even had chance to play the infinite/daily game modes yet as I've been having so much fun trying to perfect the campaign!

The controls are tight, which is really needed in a twin-stick shooter.  There is an interesting dodge mechanic in that switching between your character's primary and secondary weapons renders you temporarilty invulnerable.  This works really well and encourages you to use both of your characters' weapons to the full.

The characters are varied and interesting.  There will be a lot of replayability in terms of learning the best strategies for each android, and seeing which suits you best.

The game is slightly lacking in the visual department in places, however the fast action usually distracts you from some of the shortcomings.  The stages chopping and changing around you is a really nice touch however, and keeps the arena shooting style without being bland.

I took a bit of a punt picking up AAC, but I'm glad I did!

25372750.review:
Take note, indie developers. Hell, even some AAA developers. This is how you polish a game! 

You can clearly tell that the developers of Assault Android Cactus loved what they were creating, they shared a creative passion and wanted to bring it to life, to share it with the gaming community. And did they ever! Every single part of this game was polished until chrome, from the characters (each character has a different animation for being selected, cancelling character selection, entering a level, and completing a level, along with different primary and secondary weapons, some of which use completely different mechanics than any other character) to the boss battles (each boss is completely different, with pre-fight dialogue that's different for every character, and after defeating them you unlock new characters) to the arcade style interfaces, complete with credits and drop-ins.

Probably should mention the gameplay, because it's nothing like anything I've ever played. A top-down bullet-hell style game where getting hit doesn't matter, because what's really important is your battery. Taking damage simply stuns you, but when you're on limited battery, you really have to make sure you make every second count. I'm pretty sure that's the game's exact motto. When a battery drops, you (and your friends if you're playing coop) make a beeline for it, because that's your health. You miss a battery, you're as good as dead.

There's even special game modifiers you can buy with your credits, such as AI teammates, or even a fully fledged FIRST PERSON MODE. The developers of this game put effort into something that was completely optional, something I didn't even notice until I already beat the game. That's awesome. That should be the industry standard, like it used to be, where games boasted dozens of cheat codes that let you play it any way you wanted, because they wanted you to ENJOY WHAT THEY CREATED, not so you could line their pockets with cash.

My complaints? The game's pretty short, as the strong point of the game is definitely the boss fights.

I wish I had friends to play it with.

25370643.review: One of the most refined and fun shumps I've ever had the pleasure of playing. The graphical style is very pleasing to the eye and unique and the animations are solid. It even has a short, yet charmingly quirky story to it and one of the few I've bothered to read through in this genre. The gameplay though is what really shines. There are several modes to choose from, high scores, daily challenges, options to tweak the game, and nine characters in all. If you had one money to buy only one shoot em up game, this would be the game I'd recommend. I only hope they come out with a sequel or dlc!

25337766.review:
Make no mistake: there will be times when you hate this game. And it will hate you right back, relishing in your every misstep and failure.

That said, this is also a beautiful, smooth-running, addictive twin-stick shooter made for the hardcore arcade enthusiast. For some, it will be enough to work through the campaign for a few white knuckled hours and call it good. For others, the allure of beating your old scores and slowly creeping up the leaderboards could provide dozens of hours of replay value.

The premise is simple: pick a character with a unique attack style, and then jump in to a small arena and destroy swarms upon swarms of robots, keeping an eye out for battery powerups. You can die and resurrect an infinite number of times, but once the battery is depleted, you die for real.

The makers of this game get a standing ovation for providing a free demo to try, something that is criminally rare these days. While the demo - which features a few levels from the first zone - is deceptively easy compared to the full game, it allows you to get a good feel of the game mechanics. By all means, check it out.

At the time I'm writing this, I've only put 2.6 hours on the game. I usually play 30 minute sessions, and most of them so far have ended abruptly with me spewing hateful words at my monitor and slamming my controller down. But I always seem to come back.

(Edit: I should add that progressing through the campaign itself isn't particularly difficult; getting high grades on the individual levels is where the real difficulty is to be found.)

I've been holding off writing this review, because I cant come up with anything to make the review more than one sided. I just REALLY love this game...

I got my eyes on the game a long time ago, from Geek&Sundry on Twitch, who was showcasing it as a local Co-op shmup.
I instantly went to Steam and picked up the game myself.

At first, i struggled alot with the game. Not because i didnt like it, but because it WILL be difficult for you at first. But it's so tight, that regardless of how many times you end up running out of battery (The games life system) You want to try again and beat it.
I actually had to give up on the end boss, and return with new energy to tear it apart.

A few hundred hours later, and we now got a growing community for the game where players go head-to-head in the Daily Drive mode. Speedrun the campaign mode, and overall just have tons of fun with this very simple, but insanely well made game.

On top of all this, the sound and music is absolutely amazing. So much so, that most of us went and bought the OST to be able to listen to it anywhere. (Perfect gym score btw)

So overall, I can't give this game any less than a solid 10. Theres just nothing i can think of that would reduce that..

游戏角色：英雄都是大头萌，有御姐有萝莉，最棒的是呆萌的抠鼻机器人。每个英雄都有自己特有的攻击方式和大招可以应对不同的敌人，这个设定非常棒啊。主角打分9/10
游戏敌人：游戏里的小怪有很多种类，有不同的技能。5个BOSS也很霸气，耐打技能多，需要玩家摸索打法。BOSS战不简单但是也不会难到让人怀疑人生，方法正确就可以战胜敌人。敌人设计打分9/10

综合看，《卡图斯，进击的机器人》绝对是一款好游戏，68元花的很值。

24041008.review:
因为在多台电脑上玩耍，同步记录有一点问题，实际游玩时间已经超过20小时，才来评价一下。
首先，这是一个手感非常棒的射击游戏。除了主角Cactus是非常标准的玩法之外，其他每个角色都设计了各具特点的主副武器，角色性格也设计的很有意思。个人感觉眼镜女和大姐头是使用最方便的角色。卡了几次boss，通关时间大概在4-5小时左右。[spoiler] 最后那个N段血的boss，卡了一个多小时，最后用机器人过了。[/spoiler]
没有网络联机是一件很遗憾的事情，但游戏的本地多人非常出色，对于如此一个弹幕游戏，网络同步本身非常困难，我也不多说什么，几位辛苦了。
无限模式设计的非常好，到了紧张时刻，电力预警开始响起，心里想着快死了快死了的时候，电池就非常凑巧的在一个小怪身上爆出来了。让你不至于失败却又丝毫不敢懈怠。
另外一说，这个血量到底了可以连打复活，电量见底了只能含恨而终的设定非常热血。而且死后武器等级重置，同样会影响进度推进，使得每一次决策还是小心谨慎，每一次连打都是一次卷土重来的意气。
游戏本身还存在EX设定这种东西，把3头身拔高这件事情，当看到修改之后的选择画面，我和小伙伴相视一笑。同时就算没有同玩，也可以选择添加AI友方来增加游戏难度。
总之，如果你有一点操作的手感，喜欢这种风格，你会非常喜欢这个游戏，强烈推荐。

24007055.review:
Pros: A fantastic twin-stick shooter with local co-op, a very interesting weapon switch/dodge mechanic, and a selection of characters that each have a use.

As an added bonus, this game is actually (in my opinion) BETTER with the Steam Controller! Even without using Mouse Regions, the triggers alone made temporarily playing this with a 360 controller an agonizing experience. I also frequently have problems with my right thumb getting over the edge of a stick in intense settings like this, making me have to adjust under fire- not a problem with the Steam Controller.

Cons: Compared to what's been expected of you in every level and every boss previous to it, the final boss is BRUTAL. Unbeatable? No way. But objectively an insane jump in difficulty vs. the process that's led you to that boss? Absolutely. That's by no means a reason not to buy this game- I just feel it's a one poor design footnote in an otherwise fantastic title.

Campaign isn't so long, but it's a shooter- when are they ever? The reward is in practicing it and facing the infinite modes and achieving high scores.

Totally 10/10 if you're at all into the genre.

23530431.review:
Story  - 5/5 (Hilarious, short and spunky)
Sound - 4/5 (Could use more intensity, but very colorful)
Controls - 5/5 (tight, responsive and fun)
Gameplay - 5/5 (replay value through the roof, all modes are fun)
Graphics - 5/5 (SD Girl Androids, mucho cute. Can run at amazing FPS on a good PC, smoothly on a potato)

--

Assault Android Cactus is lock barrel shot of cocaine through your controller.

You drop down into level after level of robots gone haywire, armed with only your chosen weapon and a fun alternate heavy weapon. 

This twin stick shooter pits you up against hordes of enemies at a break neck speed, and you have to do all this while managing your battery supply (basically keeping you alive based on time, so falling down is no-no), which can only be maintained by slaughtering more robots!

Through this journey you unlock other robots with huge personalities and fun weapon styles. You can fill a Codex full of fun little bits of information, collect artwork, and even do FPS and Isometric view modes once you do enough killing. There are fun modes like Infinity Drive, which is basically survival mode. Boss Rush (unlocked after one successive play through) which pits you against all the games bosses! And Daily Drive, which gives you an interesting challenge each day. 

It's full of fun, fast paced action, and can run on a relatively normal computer without issue. Graphics are kawaii to the max, and these little big headed androids (or normal bodied, if you unlock that fun feature) tear through levels at a breakneck speed, and a moderate difficulty.

Assault Android is a short game - perhaps only 8 hours for the skilled (haha I'm not the skilled, btw~) but its countless modes, addictive multiplayer, cute unlockables, and near drug-induced levels of mayhem dazzled me to the point where I had to write a review.

Be prepared to dodge, destroy, and be an irresponsible android to your hearts content.

10/10 would play again.

Chaos with friends, chaos alone, it doesn't matter, the havoc never stops.

Heavily recommend purchase, and recommend playing with friends, preferrable with a few drinks (one of those being a red bull). 

Worth far above its price tag, an essential for the steam library.

22789481.review:
There are two things that make Cactus great. The charm, and the adrenaline rush.

The characters each have so much personality to them. I immediately connected with each of the androids as I unlocked them. There isn't much in the way of cutscenes or dialogue, but what is there is oozing with personality. From Cactus's near total disregard for property, to Shiitake's downright murderous boss-killing rampage, to Starch's... Starchiness, every character makes the game better.

Whether working through the levels to see the credits or grinding against the same level over and over for that delicious S+ ranking, Assault Android Cactus delivers on excitement. I cannot tell you how many times I grabbed a battery at the very last instant, just to turn around and demolish everything that I can see. Cactus never fails to make you feel awesome.

22744751.review: Assault Android Cactus is an arcade twin stick shooter. In the game, you can play as many characters that have their own dialogue when speaking and voice actors. This was a suprise indie game that I didn't like at first, but then got really into it. This game will keep you addicted with a campaign of levels and bosses. The cast is wonderful and fun. The O.S.T has some memorable tracks and the visuals are great. There are also daily challenges, infinite run mode, and a boss rush like most arcade like games. The battery system is intersting and keeps you at your toes. Also, the bullet hell in the boss fights are fun and a blast. If you like Pac-Man and Nuclear Throne, this game is for you. Also, all the enemies are varried and the level design is different each time so your never bored. One gripe I have with the game is that the battery has this magentic attraction to you when you go near it to get it. Yet if you move to fast, it will never reach you and result in a lot of stupid game overs. Overall, its a great game that I'm glad I was able to find and play. Thank you so much Witch Beam for this game and I'm excited for your next! I give it an 8/10.

22512515.review:
TL;DR: Lots of style, zero substance.

So far I'm pretty disappointed. I like twin stick shooters with multiplayer - it is a guaranteed way to get my money. But this? 

Regretting. Purchase. 

Gameplay is paced through code - good play is not rewarded, you can always expect a battery to drop when your alarm goes off. Powerups suck because they cycle VERY SLOWLY. One of them(and there are only *THREE*) is pretty much completely pointless.

The characters are really badly unbalanced, and chances are that you're going to find yourself defaulting to one or two most of the time because the others suck or have serious flaws or are only good for one kind of fight. Special attacks are seriously a very mixed bag, with some of them being completely and utterly pointless while others will obliterate every enemy on the screen without fail.

Spawning is also done programatically I suppose, because the game stupidly spawns crap RIGHT ON TOP OF YOU that BLOWS UP AND MAKES YOU DROP ALL OF YOUR POWERUPS . 

Well done designers, you got me. I can't escape your ineptitude now. Standing in the wrong place under the invisible spawn point? Here, let's teleport this thing in right on top of you with zero warning and no chance to dodge.

HAVE YOU A$$HOLES EVER PLAYED A SHOOTER?

Once this happens the game turns into a bull$hit $logfest that is poorly paced and unfun because you are rocking a pea shooter and the level is just ramping up.

Getting up requires button pounding. Please. Why. Just. No.

There are dozens and dozens of other little things I hate about this game. 

Utterly pointless powerups(and plentiful) blot out enemy bullets so you smack right into them. 

There is a stereotyped Asian android. 

Controller support is half-assed so you can pretty much expect that only your *official* xbox brand controller will work right. 

The camera jerks around like a jack russel terrier that's been snorting cocaine, and you can't really expect consistent camera distance while you're playing from board to board, sometimes not even within the same board.

Earning credits takes forever. Spending them is pointless, and the one or two things that actually alter gameplay dump your score over it.

Yes. If you try to evolve this game ANY it DUMPS YOUR SCORES.

And here is the absolutely number one thing that pisses me off about this game: It's some kind of indie darling because of the unusually(for indie) high quality presentation. The character visuals are polished, the voice acting is great, the graphics are wonderful and highly stylized, the animation is top notch and the facial expressions are great, the music is perfect and usually suits - but when it comes to the actual core mechanics there are some serious issues. 

To be honest I wouldn't suggest buying it unless it was on sale. This is a ho-hum twin stick shooter that looks and sounds really nice, but is INCREDIBLY SHALLOW. If you're hoping for more than that then, like me, you will probably be disappointed.

22349785.review:
Note: I'm not a professional in any way, I'm just a guy who likes writing reviews. I try to remain unbiased, but take note that this is a positive review; I like this game, so don't expect me to be thinking too clearly. :P I'm not being payed or trying to persuade you to buy the game, I'm just relating my experience.

TL;DR
Android Assault Cactus turns this type of game in its head with backwards and chaotic gameplay. While its story and graphics may not be spectacular, it makes up for it with unique and intense gameplay.
[b]Overall score: 8/10[/b]

[h1]GAMEPLAY[/h1]
You know those guys who charge around without strategy constantly firing at everything and repeatedly getting themselves killed? You know how everyone hates them for being a stupid liability? Have you ever stopped to consider how they feel or WHY exactly they have no strategy? The reason is revealed in this game; cry no more, that guy! The game pushes you to use this chaotic strategy, whether you like it or not. Guerrilla tactics, sniping, and farming have no effect as the only way to stay alive is to kill everyone as fast as possible. People who play this game will quickly learn that most power ups are worth more than your life and recklessly charge into a hoard of enemies, firing constantly. Trust me, this doesn't subtract from the strategy. To understand it better, look up gameplay. All of this makes up for how very generic the game looks at first.
 [b] [/b] [i] [/i] You thought that was all? The game gets twice as crazy when you try to get a good score. This game is no longer casual when trying to get an S+! Suddenly, local multiplayer becomes an added difficulty and life is precious. Strategy and planning are essential and must be carried out to the millisecond in order to work. Nothing less than a perfect marriage of brilliance and skill will work. (So I'm obviously at a loss. :P)
[b]Score: 8.5/10[/b] (Only because it's not completely original.)

[h1]REPLAYABILITY[/h1]
Although the game is notably long, it still has a fair amount of replayability. In fact, some can argue it has too much. With two different multiple different game modes that both focus highly on score, you could literally play this game for months without being satisfied with your completion... The definition of hell for some. However, to a less hardcore gamer, it'll still be fun for a while. After you tire of the many central elements, there's the EX options to change up the game. Among the more notable ones are FPS mode, AI partners, super weapons, duplicate characters, and [ALT CAMERA WHT DOWS IT DO]. Though for some... The immensely fun gameplay, character variety, and local multiplayer could be enough In itself. Perhaps the only problem with playing it over and over is the lack of randomness. I think the only thing that's random is the things dropped by enemies... But you could still argue that it has a great amount of replayability.
[b]Score: 8/10[/b]

[h1]GRAPHICS AND CUSTOMIZATION [/h1]
Anyone with FPS mode can say that the graphics are unnecessarily good. It has a sufficient amount of settings to suit your computer and playstyle... I'm unconcerned with graphics unless you can't see crap or if they lag my admittedly bad computer. This game does neither, so I see no problem with it. For someone who likes playing with graphics, there are plenty of options for that... Which brings me to customization. As mentioned above, you can change the graphics. Other necessary options at included, but they have extras that go above and beyond. I mentioned a few of the EX options earlier, but there are many more. Some make the game more challenging, others make it easier. Some relate to graphics and music, and others fundamentally change the game. Most are serious, some are silly. While the game isn't spectacular in either of these aspects, everyone can agree that it does well.
[b]Score: 7.5/10[/b]

[h1]STORY [/h1]
I would not buy the game for the story alone. Not that it's terrible; I've seen much worse. The problem is that it's not the BEST. The integration of story with graphics and gameplay is poor... Death robots pop up out of nowhere and brainlessly attack you, and three untrained androids manage to grab extremely powerful weapons and use them for a presumably long time with SIXTY-SECOND BATTERIES by ripping out and draining the batteries or enemies... Just ignore that. Dialogue is infrequent, but characters still have a shocking amount of personality from voice lines in and out of battle. This raises new questions about how they got to be like that, but I'll count it as a plus since personality counts for story in my book. I could go on, but I don't like saying bad things about this game. Let's just say that there are good and bad things that mostly balance each other out.
[b]Score: 4/10[/b]
